revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox civilian attack |title= Lynching of Mashal Khan |image= |image_size= |caption= |location=[[Mardan]], [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]], [[Pakistan]] |target=Mashal Khan +2 other students |date={{start date and age|2017|04|13|df=y}} |time= |timezone= [[Central Time Zone|CST]] |coordinates= |type=Mob Killing based on false accusations and rumors |weapons= gun, sticks, stones |fatalities=1 - Mashal Khan |injuries=1 - Abdullah |perp= [[Abdul Wali Khan University Mardan|Abdul Wali Khan University]] students and staffs.
47 arrested. }} '''Mashal Khan''' ({{lang-ps|مشال خان}}) was a [[Pashtuns|Pashtun]] and [[Muslim]] student at the [[Abdul Wali Khan University Mardan]], [[Pakistan]] who was [[Blasphemy law in Pakistan#Vigilantism|killed by an angry mob]] in the premises of the university on 13 April 2017, over fake allegations of posting [[Islam and blasphemy|blasphemous]] content online.{{cite news|title='Skull caved in': Pakistani journalism student beaten to death for 'blasphemy' (GRAPHIC VIDEO)|url=https://www.rt.com/news/384653-pakistan-student-beaten-to-death-journalism/|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=RT International|language=en-EN}}{{cite news|title=Pakistan 'blasphemy killing': murdered student 'devoted to Islam'|url=http://www.euronews.com/2017/04/14/pakistan-blasphemy-killing-murdered-student-devoted-to-islam|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=euronews|date=14 April 2017}}{{cite news|last1=(www.dw.com)|first1=Deutsche Welle|title=Pakistan journalism student latest victim of blasphemy vigilantes|url=http://www.dw.com/en/pakistan-journalism-student-latest-victim-of-blasphemy-vigilantes/a-38433834|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=DW.COM|language=en}} Following investigations, the Inspector General Police later stated "We did not find any concrete evidence under which [a blasphemy] investigation or legal action can be launched against Mashal, Abdullah or Zubair".{{cite|first=Anwar|last=Bangash|title=IG says no evidence against Mashal, his friends|url=http://khybernews.tv/ig-says-no-evidence-against-mashal-his-friends/|date=17 April 2017}} Mashal's friend Abdullah stated to the police in writing that both Mashal and Abdullah were devout Muslims, but were actively denouncing mismanagement by the university and had previously led protests against it. Following the death of Khan, at least 45 people were arrested. The suspects will be presented to the [[Anti Terrorism Court of Pakistan]].http://khybernews.tv/kp-police-submits-report-on-mashal-khan-murder-case-to-sc/ ==Biography== Khan completed his college in the [[Institute of Computer and Management Sciences]] on a scholarship and received good marks.{{cite news|last1=Shah|first1=Hurmat Ali|title=Only memories are left of Mashal, the idealist who always wanted to learn more|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327566/only-memories-are-left-of-mashal-the-idealist-who-always-wanted-to-learn-more|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=18 April 2017|language=en}} He then received a scholarship to study in a university in Russia{{cite news|title=Mardan lynching: Mashal's father wants killers tried in army court - The Express Tribune|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1385477/mardan-lynching-mashals-father-wants-killers-tried-army-court/|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=The Express Tribune|date=17 April 2017}} where he studied engineering for one year. He then returned to Pakistan without completing his studies due to the family's limited financial resources.{{cite news|title='There is a Mashal in every home': Father of Mardan student calls for unity, tolerance|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327346|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=16 April 2017|language=en}} Upon returning to Pakistan, he enrolled in the department of journalism at Abdul Wali Khan University Mardan and was planning to do a Master's in Mass Media and Journalism and was also preparing for his civil services exams. His father told ''[[Dawn (newspaper)|DAWN]]'' that "Mashal was devoted to his studies and would study for 15 hours a day. He believed education was essential for a full life and encouraged his brother and sisters to study as well. His father added that Mashal was a "peaceful, tolerant person." and that he wrote poetry in [[Pashto language|Pashto]]. Khan had one brother and two sisters and was 23 years old at the time of his murder.{{cite news|last1=Shah|first1=Sadia Qasim|title=Of indifference and empathy|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327118/of-indifference-and-empathy|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=15 April 2017|language=en}}{{cite news|title=Mobsters lynch Mardan student over 'blasphemy'|url=http://dailytimes.com.pk/pakistan/14-Apr-17/mobsters-lynch-mardan-student-over-blasphemy|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=dailytimes.com.pk|language=en}} [[Geo News]] reported that his teacher told it "Mashal was a humanist, he was into socialism and Sufism".{{cite news|title=Teacher says Mashal was not given chance to prove his innocence|url=https://www.geo.tv/latest/138460-Teacher-resigns-apologises-to-nation-for-failure-to-save-Mashal|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=www.geo.tv}}{{cite news|title='University admin responsible for lynching,' says Mashal Khan's teacher|url=http://nation.com.pk/national/18-Apr-2017/university-admin-responsible-for-lynching-says-mashal-khan-s-teacher|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=The Nation}} A teacher described Khan as an engaged and thoughtful student. "He was brilliant and inquisitive, always complaining about the political system of the country, but I never heard him saying anything controversial against the religion."{{cite news|last1=Metro.co.uk|first1=Jimmy Nsubuga for|title=Students 'beat fellow pupil to death after accusing him of blasphemy'|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/04/13/students-beat-fellow-pupil-to-death-after-accusing-him-of-blasphemy-6574197/|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=Metro|date=13 April 2017}} ==Incident== ===Background=== ;National politics and blasphemy In March 2017, the Prime Minister of Pakistan Nawaz Sharif [[Internet censorship in Pakistan|supported a crackdown]] on blasphemous material posted on social media and described blasphemy as an "unpardonable offence".{{cite news|title=Pakistani student accused of blasphemy beaten to death on campus|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-pakistan-blasphemy-idUSKBN17F1ZL|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=Reuters|date=13 April 2017}} ;Mashal Khan criticisms of AWK University's administrators Before his death Mashal Khan criticized the Abdul Wali Khan University but none of his comments mentioned religion or contained blasphemy. He revealed that the vice-chancellor never attended the university and students were forced to study in uncertainty of whether or not they would receive the degrees for which they were studying. He criticised teachers, accused them of bureaucracy and said that a single faculty member was in charge of multiple responsibilities. According to him "everyone in authority is a thief here." The way the university collected outstanding dues was also criticised as it charged students Rs. 25,000, while other universities only collected Rs. 5,000.{{cite news|title=Mashal Khan Revealed Shocking Details About His University In An Interview Before His Death!|url=https://www.parhlo.com/mashal-khan-interview/|accessdate=24 April 2017}} ===Mob and murder=== [[File:April_13,_2017,_Assistant_Registrar,_Abdul_Wali_Khan_University_Mardan.jpg|thumb|13 April announcement, as published by the [[Abdul Wali Khan University Mardan]] on its April 2017's online board.http://awkum.edu.pk/News_Archive/5_News_2017/04_April_2017/News_Archive_April_2017.html The announcement was later modified and republished on 14 April, with a red "WITHDRAWN" stamp, [http://awkumpk.blogspot.fr/2017/04/notifications-from-office-of-registrar.html the webpage] was later deleted on 25 April.]] On 13 April 2017, the assistant registrar posted an official notice on the online board announcing that three students were under investigation for blasphemous activities, and had been suspended:{{cite|title=Students at Pakistani university lynch classmate falsely accused of blasphemy|url=https://theintercept.com/2017/04/14/students-pakistani-university-lynch-classmate-falsely-accused-blasphemy/|first=Robert|last=Mackey|date=14 April 2017}} {{quote|I am directed to notify that the following Inquiry Committee has been constituted to probe into the matter of blasphemous activities carried by the students of Department of Journalism namely, Mr. Abdullah, Mr. Mashal and Mr. Zubair. Further, the mentioned students are hereby rusticated and their entry into the premises of the University (all campuses) is banned until further orders|13 April 2017. Assistant Registrar, Abdul Wali Khan University Mardan}} A large group of students formed into a mob, accusing these students of running a Facebook page where Mashal was allegedly publishing blasphemous material. Mashal was killed inside the premises of the [[Abdul Wali Khan University Mardan]] where he was a student of mass communication.{{cite news|last1=Farhan|first1=Reuters | Ali Akbar | Hassan|title=Mardan university student lynched by mob over alleged blasphemy: police|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1326729/mardan-university-student-lynched-by-mob-over-alleged-blasphemy-police|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=13 April 2017|language=en}}{{cite news|last1=Correspondent|first1=Sana Jamal,|title=Pakistan university student beaten to death over alleged blasphemy|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/asia/pakistan/pakistan-university-student-beaten-to-death-over-alleged-blasphemy-1.2011396|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=GulfNews|date=14 April 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Kishore|first1=Divya|title=Pakistani student beaten to death over blasphemous content on social media|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/pakistani-student-beaten-death-over-blasphemous-content-social-media-1616988|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=International Business Times UK|date=14 April 2017}}{{cite news|last1=http://www.washingtontimes.com|first1=The Washington Times|title=Abdul Wali Khan professor: Student killed by Pakistani mob 'didn't understand the environment'|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/apr/14/abdul-wali-khan-professor-student-killed-by-pakist/|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=The Washington Times}} Khan's death was filmed through mobile phones and was shared on social media.{{cite news|title=Student lynched over "blasphemy"|url=http://www.euronews.com/2017/04/14/student-lynched-over-blasphemy|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=euronews|date=14 April 2017}} At least 25 policemen were present in the university premises when Khan was killed.{{cite news|last1=Zaidi|first1=Mubashir|title=Pakistani student killed over alleged blasphemy|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/pakistani-student-killed-over-alleged-blasphemy/article17992006.ece|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=The Hindu|language=en}} He was in the hostel of the university when he was stripped naked and severely beaten by a group of students and then shot. He succumbed to his injuries.{{cite news|title=Pakistan: Eight charged for journalism student's murder|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/04/pakistan-charged-journalism-student-murder-170415104542323.html|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=www.aljazeera.com}} Graphic video footage of the lynching showed Khan was lying on the floor; his body bore marks of severe torture and was not moving. The mob was seen kicking his lifeless body and beating it with wooden planks. He was also thrown from the second floor of the building. Several more videos emerged later which showed him alive and the mob mercilessly attacking him. Deputy Inspector General of Police said the mob wanted to burn the body of Khan after he was dead.{{cite news|title=Pakistan university closes after journalism student lynched for 'blasphemy'|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/pak-university-closes-after-journalism-student-lynched-for-blasphemy/story-s5VyKbV1tF5lwCAFW8gBxL.html|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=www.hindustantimes.com/|date=14 April 2017|language=en}}{{cite news|title=Student murdered by mob over "blasphemy" at Pakistan university|url=http://www.trtworld.com/asia/student-murdered-by-mob-over-blasphemy-at-pakistan-university-336109|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=TRT World|language=tr-TR}} It was reported that some leaders of the student body were part of the mob that attacked Khan.{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/media/digital/2017/04/13/-Blasphemy-Journalism-student-killed-in-Pakistan-for-Facebook-posts.html |title='Blasphemy': Journalism student killed in Pakistan for Facebook posts |deadurl=no |accessdate=15 April 2017}} A senior police officer said "Hundreds of people were involved and Khan was badly tortured after being shot at a close range. He was beaten with sticks, bricks and hands."{{cite news|title=Pakistan student killed over 'blasphemy' on university campus|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-39593302|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=BBC News|date=13 April 2017}} An eyewitness at the scene of the incident said Khan was attacked because he was believed to be promoting the Ahmadi faith on Facebook. Reports say a university administrator and several leaders of the university's student body were part of the attacking mob.http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/pakistan/in-pakistan-journalism-student-lynched-by-screaming-mob-for-blasphemy/articleshow/58175291.cms An unknown official at the university said "Khan was disliked by other students for his liberal and secular views." At least 20 police officers were present at the scene, but they were unable to control the situation. The university campus was shut down following his death and its hostels were vacated to avoid a further escalation of violence. ==Mashal Khan's funeral== On the following day (14 April), Mashal Khan's funeral was led by his father, a local poet. Most neighbours kept away from the funeral, as threats made earlier by a local to anyone attending led them to fear follow-up attacks from religious mobs.{{cite|title=I attended Mashal Khan's funeral prayer, when others refused: Sherin Yousafzai|last=Yousafzai|first=Sherin |url=https://www.geo.tv/latest/138922-I-attended-Mashal-Khans-funeral-prayers-when-others-refused|year=2017}} Some elders nevertheless joined, calling over neighbours to show support and a few dozen people eventually joined the procession. In the following days, as information and national support emerged, neighbours expressed regret for not being able to protect Mashal nor supporting the Khans more on the day of the funeral. ==Investigation and arrests== Following the death of Khan, at least 45 people were arrested. ===Initial Investigation=== According to police investigations, Mashal Khan had not carried out any blasphemous action. The Inspector General Police stated "We did not find any concrete evidence under which an investigation or legal action can be launched against Mashal, Abdullah or Zubair". According to Abdullah, the AWK University's administration summoned him to the Mass Communications chairman's office, where they pressured him into accusing Mashal of blasphemy. When Abdullah refused as "Neither Mashal nor I had committed any blasphemy", the administration issued the online notification, then went to punish Abdullah by beating and Mashal by lynching. According to the testimony of one of the prime accused, Wajahat Ullah, collected by the police, 15 to 20 persons were at the office of the chairman discussing the three students' controversial views when he was called over by fellow student Mudassar Bashir, the representative of the class.{{cite|last=Ali|first=Arshad|year=2017|date=|title=Mardan University security incharge incited mob to murder Mashal: prime accused|url=http://khybernews.tv/76681-2/}} Lecturers Ziaullah Hamdard and Pir Asfandyar, clerks Anees, Saeed and Idrees, and superintendent Arshad were present and summoned him on the issue. Class representative Mudassar Bashir asked him to become a witness of the alleged blasphemy, while clerk Idrees repeated his opposition to having a communist in AWK University. The proposition of creating a committee of inquiry was opposed by clerk Idrees and class leader Bashir, while security in-charge Bilal Bakhsh declared his will to handle the issue quickly, occasionally stating his will to kill the student. The group processed toward Mashal's hostel, calling for bystanders to join and turning the expedition into an angry punitive mob. ===Arrests=== On 21 April, AWKUM's superintendent and office's assistant were imprisoned on judicial remand.{{cite|first=Farhan|last=Khan|date=21 April 2017|url=http://khybernews.tv/mashal-lynching-case-superintendent-awkum-imprisoned-on-judicial-remand/|title=MASHAL LYNCHING CASE: SUPERINTENDENT AWKUM SENT TO JAIL ON JUDICIAL REMAND}} Some of the accused were sent to the Anti-Terrorism Court (ATC). Bilal Baksh, a computer operator at the university, was alleged to have shouted slogans and called for a mob to build around Mr. Khan and murder him.{{cite|first=Farhan|last=Khan|title=AWKUM computer operator arrested in Mashal Khan murder case|url=http://khybernews.tv/awkum-computer-operator-arrested-in-mashal-khan-murder-case/|date=23 April 2017}} Two other suspect were delivered to ATC. {{cite|first=Farhan|last=Khan|date=24 April 2017|title=Mashal Khan murder case: ATC hands over two suspects to police on remand|url=http://khybernews.tv/mashal-khan-murder-case-atc-hands-over-two-suspects-to-police-on-remand/}} On 25 April, 2 other suspects were handed over to ATC. {{cite|first=Farhan|last=Khan|date=25 April 2017|title=Two more key suspects arrested in Mashal Khan's lynching: DPO Mardan|url=http://khybernews.tv/two-more-key-suspects-arrested-in-mashal-khans-lynching-dpo-mardan/}} It was reported that the administration of the university, through a notification dated 13 April 2017, rusticated Khan and decided to investigate Khan for alleged "blasphemous activity". A provost of the university said the notification was issued after the death of Khan.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1326944/mardan-university-takes-action-against-victims-launches-probe-into-blasphemous-activity|title=Mardan university takes action against victims; launches probe into 'blasphemous activity'|last=Akbar|first=Dawn.com {{!}} Ali|date=14 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|accessdate=14 April 2017|language=en}} {| class="wikitable" ! Arrested || Status || Accusation |- | Imran Ali{{cite|first=Arshad |last=Ali|date=27 April 2017|title=Mashal Khan's shooter arrested: DIG Mardan|url=http://khybernews.tv/mashal-khans-shooter-arrested-dig-mardan/}}{{cite|first=Anwar |last=Bangash|date=29 April 2017|title=Main accused in Mashal lynching case confesses his role |url=http://khybernews.tv/main-accused-in-mashal-lynching-case-confesses-his-role/}} (student) || ATC || Shot Mashal thrice, charged for murder. |- | Afsar Khan (AWKUM superintendent) || || n.a. |- | Bilal Baksh (AWKUM computer operator) || || Inciting a mob in order to lynch/murder the victim |- | Bilal Bux (in-charge of security in AWKUM) || ATC || n.a. (identified on video) |- | Amir (student) || ATC || n.a. (identified on video) |- | Ashfaq Khelji || ATC || Hitting Mashal Khan in the head with a flowerpot (identified on video) |- | Fazal Raziq || ATC || Desecrated Mashal's corpse (identified on video) |- | Tariq Khanhttp://khybernews.tv/police-arrested-another-accuse-for-involvement-in-mashal-khan-murder/ (student of AWKU's mass communication) || || |- | Ishaq Khan (student from nearby university) || || |- | Abbas{{cite|first=Farhan|last=Khan|title=Mashal Khan's shooter handed over to police on remand|url=http://khybernews.tv/mashal-khans-shooter-handed-over-to-police-on-remand/|date=28 April 2017}} (student) || ATC || n.a. |- | Suleman (student) || ATC || n.a. |- | Usman (student) || ATC || n.a. |- | Shabir Ahmed (AWKUM staff) || ATC || n.a. |- | Nawab Ali (AWKUM staff) || ATC || n.a. |- | colspan="3"| |} ===JIT Report=== The 13-member Joint Investigation Team (JIT) constituted by the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan]] in response to the lynching gave its final report on 3 June 2017. The report cleared Mashal of all blasphemy charges and termed his lynching a premeditated murder conducted by certain elements in the student body and the university administration. The report also cleared Mashal's two friends, Abdullah and Zubair, of any blasphemy while raising questions about the efficacy of Mardan Police's response to the incident.{{cite web|last1=Firdous|first1=Iftikhar|title=Plot to 'get rid of' Mashal Khan was hatched a month before murder, concludes JIT|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1427069/plot-get-rid-mashal-khan-hatched-month-murder-concludes-jit/|website=The Express Tribune}}{{cite web|title=JIT finds a student group incited mob against Mashal|url=https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/06/04/jit-finds-a-student-group-incited-mob-against-mashal/|website=Pakistan Today}}{{cite web|last1=Akbar|first1=Ali|title=Mashal murder case: JIT finds group in university incited mob against student on pretext of blasphemy|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1337373/mashal-murder-case-jit-finds-group-in-university-incited-mob-against-student-on-pretext-of-blasphemy|website=Dawn.com}} According to the report, the two prime inciters of the lynching were Sabir Mayer, president of the [[Pukhtoon Students Federation]], and Ajmal Khan, president of the university's employee union. Ajmal confessed that a month before the lynching, Sabir, along with a university employee, Asad Katlang, came to his office and told him that they had to "get rid of Mashal" as he was a "threat to the party" (the 'party' is presumed to be the leftist political party, [[Awami National Party]], whose student federation Sabir headed). The trio then proceeded to hatch a plan for Mashal's murder. As stated in the report, the prime reason for Mashal's lynching was his constant criticism of the university's administration. A month before his lynching, he gave a television interview to [[AVT Khyber]], a regional news channel, in which he alleged that illegal and criminal activities persisted in the university hostel and female students were also exploited in the university. It was further found that the university had serious management issues where top posts were filled by people of criminal background due to their political affiliation. It has been suggested in the report that strict departmental action should be taken against registrar Sher Alam, director administration Peer Asfandyar, chief security officer Inayatullah Afridi, provost Fayaz Ali Shah, chief proctor professor Idrees, director sports professor Farooq and assistant registrar Humyaun for their incompetence. In its conclusion, the report, which will be submitted to the Supreme Court and the anti-terrorism court (ATC), has suggested severe punishments for the university employees and students involved in the crime. ==Reaction== ===Government=== *Prime Minister [[Nawaz Sharif]] issued a condemnation of the lynching of Khan, saying that "I am shocked and saddened by the senseless display of mob justice that resulted in the murder of a young student, Mashal Khan, at Wali Khan University, Mardan. The nation should stand united to condemn this crime and to promote tolerance and rule of law in the society."{{cite news|title=Nation must be united in condemning Mashal Khan's murder: PM Nawaz|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327160/nation-must-be-united-in-condemning-mashal-khans-murder-pm-nawaz|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=15 April 2017|language=en}} He directed the police to arrest those who were responsible and ordered action against them.{{cite news|title=PM Nawaz urges nation to unite in condemning Mashal Khan's lynching - The Express Tribune|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1384572/pm-nawaz-urges-nation-unite-condemning-mashal-khans-lynching/|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=The Express Tribune|date=15 April 2017}} *Members of the [[National Assembly of Pakistan]] passed a unanimous resolution to condemn the murder of Khan.{{cite news|last1=Bilal|first1=Muhammad|title=NA unanimously condemns Mashal's murder|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327743/na-unanimously-condemns-mashals-murder|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=18 April 2017|language=en}} *Members of the [[Senate of Pakistan]] condemned the murder and suggested amending the blasphemy law to punish those who make false blasphemy accusations against others.{{cite news|last1=Khan|first1=Iftikhar A.|title=Senators call for amending blasphemy law|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327674/senators-call-for-amending-blasphemy-law|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=18 April 2017|language=en}} *Members of the [[Provincial Assembly of Balochistan]] condemned the murder of Khan.{{cite news|last1=Correspondent|first1=The Newspaper's Staff|title=Balochistan Assembly condemns Mashal's murder|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327679/balochistan-assembly-condemns-mashals-murder|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=18 April 2017|language=en}} *Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Chief Minister [[Pervez Khattak]] said no evidence had been found to suggest Khan had committed blasphemy.{{cite news|last1=Farhan|first1=Mohammad Ashfaq | Inamullah Khattak | Ali Akbar | Hassan|title=No evidence found to suggest Mashal Khan committed blasphemy: CM Khattak|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327151|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=15 April 2017|language=en}} * A senior police officer, who wanted to remain anonymous, said that "many members of the police, prosecution service and judiciary sympathised with the attackers and he did not expect any guilty verdicts" and added that "there are hundreds of sympathisers in my force and if I take too much interest in the case I might be killed too".{{cite news|title=No evidence to suggest Mashal Khan committed blasphemy: K-P IG|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1385975/no-evidence-suggest-mardan-university-students-committed-blasphemy-k-p-ig/|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=[[The Express Tribune]]|date=17 April 2017}} ===Individuals=== *[[Imran Khan]] also issued condemnation and said that "The law of the jungle can't prevail."{{cite news|last1=Desk|first1=Interactive|title=How did politicians condemn Mashal Khan's brutal killing?|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327161/how-did-politicians-condemn-mashal-khans-brutal-killing|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=15 April 2017|language=en}}{{cite news|title=DailyTimes {{!}} Imran Khan condemns Mashal Khan's murder|url=http://dailytimes.com.pk/pakistan/14-Apr-17/imran-khan-condemns-mashal-khans-murder|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=dailytimes.com.pk|language=en}} and "even if Mashal Khan was accused of committing blasphemy, he should have been given a right of defence."{{cite news|last1=Raza|first1=Syed Irfan|title=COAS agreed to help hold fair polls: Imran|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327683/coas-agreed-to-help-hold-fair-polls-imran|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=18 April 2017|language=en}} A day later, he said "I want to assure parents of Khan that I will ensure justice for his death. Even if the culprits are found to be from the PTI, they will be punished. We will not discriminate along party lines in pursuing this case."{{cite news|title='We will make sure no one misuses the blasphemy law again'|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327745/we-will-make-sure-no-one-misuses-the-blasphemy-law-again|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=18 April 2017|language=en}} *[[Malala Yousafzai]] condemned the killing of Khan saying that "We have forgotten our values. We are not representing the true Islam. "No one is maligning the name of your country or religion…we ourselves are bringing a bad name to our country and religion. If we will continue killing each other like this, then no one will be ever safe."{{cite news|title=We're bringing a bad name to Islam ourselves: Malala condemns Mashal Khan's murder - The Express Tribune|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1384391/bringing-bad-name-islam-malala-condemns-mashal-khans-murder/|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=The Express Tribune|date=15 April 2017}}{{cite news|title=Malala condemns Mashal's murder, says we are bringing a bad name to Islam ourselves|url=https://www.geo.tv/latest/138125-Malala-strongly-criticizes-Mashals-killing-in-video-message|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=www.geo.tv}} *Sheikh Saleh Al Talib who was present in Pakistan at the time of incident, said "when it comes to accusing someone of blasphemy, there are two types of people, those who are illiterate and those who misuse Islam for personal gains.{{cite news|title=People who cast blasphemy accusations need to be educated, says Imam-i-Kaaba|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327427/people-who-cast-blasphemy-accusations-need-to-be-educated-says-imam-i-kaaba|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=17 April 2017|language=en}} * [[Awami National Party]] (ANP) President [[Asfandyar Wali Khan]] said, "No culprit, no matter who he is, should be spared from punishment. Even hang my son if he is involved in Mashal's lynching.https://tribune.com.pk/story/1386912/hang-son-involved-mashals-lynching-says-asfandyar-wali/?amp=1 * Neighbours. The residents of Mashal Khan's native town, Zaida, gathered at the grave of Mashal Khan and apologised to the deceased and his family for failing to 'stand with them in crisis'. The villagers acknowledged that they made a mistake by initially not standing with the family. The people later laid a wreath at the student's grave and offered fateha for him. They also staged a demonstration to demand justice for the student's family through punishment of killers and accomplices.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1328261/neighbours-apologise-to-mashals-family-for-indifference|title=Neighbours apologise to Mashal's family for indifference|last=Khan|first=Muqaddam|date=2017-04-21|work=DAWN.COM|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en}} ===Public=== Following the murder of Khan, protests were held in different parts of Pakistan over the murder of Khan.{{cite news|title=Protests in Pakistan against lynching of student Mashal Khan; accused of alleged blasphemy|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/protests-in-pakistan-against-lynching-of-student-mashal-khan-accused-of-alleged-blasphemy/story-8a48N4KCDoNlHPMK1y7UEI.html|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=15 April 2017|language=en}} A large number of people took to streets in Khan's village in Swabi. ''[[Dawn (newspaper)|DAWN]]'' reported that "It was probably for the first time that a large number of women participated in a mourning procession in the area."{{cite news|last1=Hoti|first1=Jamal|last2=Khan|first2=Muqaddam|title=Men, women protest lynching, lay wreaths on Mashal's grave|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327522/men-women-protest-lynching-lay-wreaths-on-mashals-grave|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|date=17 April 2017|language=en}} Progressive students and youth organized protests and public meetings against this brutal killing in many cities across the country.{{cite news|title= Student's lynching sparks rare uproar in Pakistan over blasphemy killings|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/apr/26/lynching-of-a-student-sparks-uproar-in-pakistan-against-blasphemy-laws|accessdate=26 April 2017|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=26 April 2017|language=en}} All these protests inside the country and solidarity campaign across the world demanded to put pressure on Pakistani State to take action against the murderers. Due to these protests many religious scholars had to announce Khan as a Martyr which shows the intensity of public outrage at this murder.{{cite news|title=Ulema from all sects should unanimously condemn misuse of blasphemy law |url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1327170|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=[[Dawn.com|Dawn]]|date=15 April 2017|language=en}} On the 40th day after the death of Mashal Khan a public meeting was held in his village in which students and political activists participated in large numbers and asked for exemplary punishment of Mashal's killers. At this meeting which was attended by students of Quaid-e-Azam University Islamabad, Peshawar University and Malakand University among others was addressed by leaders of various political parties. At the end Khan's father Iqbal Khan addressed the meeting and said that, "Let's make the universities and other educational institutions so peaceful that in future no student falls prey to mob assault like my son."{{cite news|last2=Khan|first2=Muqaddam|title=Political parties call for exemplary punishment to Mashal's killers|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1334676|accessdate=22 May 2017|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|date=22 May 2017|language=en}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Khan, Mashal}} [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:2017 murders in Asia]] [[Category:2017 crimes in Pakistan]] [[Category:April 2017 crimes in Asia]] [[Category:April 2017 events in Pakistan]] [[Category:People murdered in Pakistan]] [[Category:Human rights abuses in Pakistan]] [[Category:Abdul Wali Khan University alumni]] [[Category:Blasphemy law in Pakistan]] [[Category:People persecuted by Muslims]] [[Category:Pakistani humanists]] [[Category:Islam-related controversies]] [[Category:Lynching deaths in Pakistan]] [[Category:Deaths by person]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox referendum | name = Question 1: Citizen Initiative | title = '''An Act to Allow Marriage Licenses for Same-Sex Couples and Protect Religious Freedom''' | yes = 370770 | no = 334049 | total = 721791 | map = Maine marriage question 2012.svg | mapdivision = county | mapcaption = {{legend|#00d700|Yes—60-70%}} {{legend|#00ff00|Yes—50-60%}} {{legend|#e27f90|No—50-60%}} {{legend|#cc2f4a|No—60-70%}} | notes = Source: [http://maineelections.bangordailynews.com/ Maine 2012 General Election Results - BDN Maine], [http://www.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/2012/refstate1112.xls Tabulation of Votes] }} {{ElectionsME}} '''Maine Question 1''' was a voter referendum on an initiated state statute that occurred November 6, 2012. The title of the citizen initiative is "An Act to Allow Marriage Licenses for Same-Sex Couples and Protect Religious Freedom". The question that appeared on the ballot was: "Do you want to allow the [[State of Maine]] to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples?" The law took effect on December 29, 2012.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5h5x18bf8Ysv4kNG7YDOvlCBROHYA?docId=4bf93adb278c450391c481978e11df20 Gay marriage law goes into effect in Maine] ==Background== In 2009, same-sex marriage legalization, "An Act To End Discrimination in Civil Marriage and Affirm Religious Freedom", was passed by the legislature and signed into law by Governor [[John Baldacci]]. A 2009 people's veto [[Maine Question 1, 2009|referendum]] to reject the law passed 53 to 47 percent, invalidating the law before it took effect. On June 30, 2011, [[EqualityMaine]] and [[Gay & Lesbian Advocates & Defenders]] (GLAD) announced plans to place a voter initiative in support of same-sex marriage on Maine's November 2012 ballot.{{cite web |work=Portland Press Herald |url=http://www.pressherald.com/news/maine-Gay-marriage-referendum.html |first=David |last=Sharp |title=Gay marriage supporters aiming for 2012 referendum |date=June 30, 2011 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}} Supporters delivered more than 105,000 petition signatures for the initiative to the Secretary of State's office on January 26, 2012, exceeding the minimum of 57,277 signatures requirement.{{cite web |url=http://www.sunjournal.com/comment/91821 |title=It's on: Same-sex marriage supporters give it another try|date=January 26, 2012 |author=Steve Mistler |work=Lewiston Sun Journal}}{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |first=Glenn |last=Adams |date=January 26, 2012 |url=http://www.timesunion.com/news/article/Maine-poised-for-2nd-public-vote-on-gay-marriage-2691837.php |title=Maine poised for 2nd public vote on gay marriage |publisher=Times-Union}} The Secretary of State announced on February 23 that the office verified 85,216 signatures, qualifying the initiative for the November 2012 ballot.{{cite web |url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/02/23/politics/secretary-of-state-says-same-sex-marriage-will-be-on-the-ballot/ |title=Secretary of state says same-sex marriage will be on the ballot |date=February 23, 2012 |first=Judy |last=Harrison |publisher=Bangor Daily News}} Under Maine's constitution a valid initiative must be sent to the voters unless enacted in the proposed form by the Legislature at the same session during which it was presented. In March 2012, the Maine Legislature voted to indefinitely postpone the initiative without debate, effectively putting it on the November ballot.{{cite web |url=http://www.wmtw.com/r/30667750/detail.html |title=Maine Same-Sex Marriage Bill Step Closer To Voters |date=March 13, 2012 |publisher=WMTV}}{{cite web |url=http://www.onlinesentinel.com/news/Same-sex-marriage-officially-on-November-ballot.html |title=Same-sex marriage closer to November ballot |first=Susan M. |last=Cover |publisher=Morning Sentinel |date=March 13, 2012}}[http://www.seacoastonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20120315/NEWS/203150397/-1/NEWSMAP Senate sends gay marriage question to Maine voters] ==Ballot question== On June 14, 2012, [[Secretary of State of Maine|Maine Secretary of State]] [[Charlie Summers]], who opposed same-sex marriage,{{cite web |url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/06/20/politics/more-words-needed-in-same-sex-marriage-ballot-question-supporters-say/ |title=Supporters want a wordier same-sex marriage question on November's ballot |date=June 20, 2012 |accessdate=June 22, 2012}} released the draft wording of the question as it would appear on the ballot, beginning a 30-day public comment period, at the end of which he had ten days to determine the wording of the question.{{cite web |url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/06/14/politics/draft-of-gay-marriage-question-released/ |title=Draft of Maine same-sex marriage question released |date=June 14, 2012 |accessdate=June 22, 2012}} He proposed the following wording: {{quote|Do you want to allow same-sex couples to marry?}} The petitions that supporters circulated was as follows:{{cite web |work=Bangor Daily News |url=http://bangordailynews.com/2011/08/17/politics/same-sex-marriage-petition-approved/ |first=Eric |last=Russell |title=Signature-gathering campaign to begin on Maine same-sex marriage initiative |date=August 17, 2011 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}} {{quote|Do you favor a law allowing marriage licenses for same-sex couples, and that protects religious freedom by ensuring that no religion or clergy be required to perform such a marriage in violation of their religious beliefs?}} Opponents of the initiative claimed that latter part of the circulated question is unnecessary, as the religious freedom to refuse to perform same-sex marriages is guaranteed by the [[First Amendment of the United States Constitution]]. They also criticized the wording for failing to mention redefining marriage. Supporters of the initiative said the Secretary of State's proposed wording "fails to address important parts of the initiative that will be on the ballot in November". Though they concede the First Amendment point made by the measure's opponents, they asked Summers, whose good faith they did not question, to restore the reference to protecting religious freedom because they claim opponents "distort the {{sic|facts |hide=y|around}} what the approval of same-sex marriage will do, including the possibility that churches would lose their tax-exempt status by refusing to perform same-sex marriages." The final wording Summers chose is "Do you want to allow the State of Maine to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples?" Representatives of both sides of the issue stated they had no major problems with Summers' decision.{{cite web |work=Bangor Daily News |url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/07/26/politics/final-wording-of-same-sex-marriage-question-issued/ |first=Judy |last=Harrison |title=Final wording of same-sex marriage question issued |date=July 26, 2012 |accessdate=July 26, 2012}} ==Campaign== EqualityMaine and Mainers United for Marriage began the campaign for the initiative on May 15, 2012.{{cite web |url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/05/15/news/state/same-sex-marriage-supporters-kick-off-maine-campaign-by-going-door-to-door/?ref=latest |title=Same-sex marriage supporters kick off Maine campaign by going door to door |date=May 15, 2012 |first=Judy |last=Harrison |publisher=Bangor Daily News}} By June 28, Mainers United for Marriage had raised over $1 million, and 64 percent of those contributions had come from within Maine.{{cite web |url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/06/28/politics/same-sex-marriage-supporters-say-theyve-raised-1-million/ |title=Same-sex marriage supporters say they've raised $1 million |date=June 28, 2012 |accessdate=June 28, 2012}} On July 23, the Maine ACLU and Mainers United for Marriage held a press conference to announce the formation of the group [[Maine Republican Party|Republican]]s United for Marriage as part of an effort to attract more Republican support of the initiative. Fifteen Republicans appeared at the conference, including three current [[Maine Legislature|state legislators]]. One of those, Rep. Stacey Fitts of [[Pittsfield, Maine|Pittsfield]], had voted against the 2009 same-sex marriage law passed by the previous Legislature but stated that he has now changed his mind after discussions with gay persons that he knows and his family. Fitts also said he felt his new views were a "perfect match" with his Republican philosophy of small government.{{cite web |url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/07/23/politics/same-sex-marriage-advocates-introduce-republican-supporters/ |title=Same-sex marriage advocates introduce Republican supporters|date=July 23, 2012 |accessdate=July 23, 2012}} Pastor Bob Emerich, a spokesman for initiative opponents, dismissed the announcement as "insignificant" and questioned "why these people even call themselves Republicans."{{cite web |url=http://www.kjonline.com/news/Gay-marriage-group-to-unveil-Republican-supporters.html |title=Marriage equality group unveils Republican supporters|date=July 23, 2012 |accessdate=July 23, 2012}} [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]], through a spokesperson, endorsed the initiative on October 24.{{cite news|last=Stone|first=Matthew|title=Obama backs Maine’s same-sex marriage measure|url=http://capitolincite.bangordailynews.com/2012/10/25/obama-backs-maines-same-sex-marriage-measure/|accessdate=25 October 2012|newspaper=Bangor Daily News|date=25 October 2012}} [[Richard Joseph Malone|Richard Malone]], former [[Catholicism|Catholic]] Bishop of [[Portland, Maine|Portland]], stated on October 25 that supporting the initiative was "unfaithful to Catholic doctrine" and that Catholics whose conscience was formed through scripture could not justify voting for any candidate or referendum that opposes the teachings of the Church. He said that Catholics for Marriage Equality did not speak for the Catholic Church.{{cite web |url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/10/25/politics/ex-maine-bishop-says-voting-for-gay-marriage-unfaithful-to-catholic-doctrine/ |title=Former Maine bishop says voting for gay marriage 'unfaithful to Catholic doctrine'|date=October 25, 2012 |accessdate=October 25, 2012}} Democratic [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representatives]] [[Chellie Pingree]] and [[Mike Michaud]] both stated they intended to vote in favor of the referendum, while Republican [[United States Senate|U.S. Senators]] [[Susan Collins]] and [[Olympia Snowe]] both stated that their policy was to not comment on state level issues. [[Governor of Maine|Governor]] [[Paul LePage]], through his spokeswoman, also declined to offer his views on the referendum.{{cite web|url=http://www.kjonline.com/politics/most-maine-top-elected-officials-steer-clear-of-gay-marriage-issue_2012-11-04.html|title=Most Maine top elected officials steer clear of gay-marriage issue|publisher=Kennebec Journal |date=November 5, 2012 |accessdate=November 21, 2012}} Collins and Snowe would both state their support for same-sex marriage after the referendum.{{cite web|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2013/04/05/now-out-of-senate-snowe-supports-same-sex-marriage/|publisher=CNN |title=Now out of Senate, Snowe supports same-sex marriage|author=Lisa Desjardins|date=April 5, 2013|accessdate=April 5, 2013}}{{cite web|title=Susan Collins: I support same-sex marriage|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2014/06/25/politics/elections/susan-collins-i-support-same-sex-marriage/|date=June 25, 2014}} The referendum was declared passed on November 6, 2012 by the Associated Press, and opposition group Protect Marriage Maine conceded at 1:30 am on November 7, 2012.{{cite news|last=Cover|first=Susan|title=Mainers vote to legalize same-sex marriage|url=http://www.pressherald.com/politics/Same-sex-marriage-question-challenges-voters-from-the-heart.html|accessdate=7 November 2012|newspaper=Portland Press Herald|date=7 November 2012}} 53% of Maine voted in favor. ==Polling== {| class="wikitable" style="width:825px;" !Date of opinion poll !Conducted by ![[Sample size]]

{{Orphan|date=January 2015}}
'''Migu''' or ''miggo'' (translation: "since") (Hebrew: מיגו) is a [[Talmudic law]] concept relating to civil law disputes. A migu is a reason that a claim that would otherwise be rejected by a Jewish civil court should be accepted based on the fact that the [[litigant]] could have prevailed in the case based on a different claim were he disposed to lie. To be effective, the logic underlying the migu must be impeccable and there are a variety of cases in which the Migu argument is invalid.
==Example of an effective Migu==
One classic example of where a Migu does work is in the area of a [[loan]] repayment dispute. Where the [[lender]] accuses an alleged borrower of [[default (law)|default]]ing on an oral loan made without witnesses, the borrower may prevail in the case by claiming that the loan did occur, but that it had already been repaid. Normally, when one makes a claim that a loan has been repaid, he would be expected to produce evidence that it had been repaid, such as a [[receipt]]. However, in this scenario the borrower would prevail under the theory that he must be telling the truth, as if he were interested in lying to the court, he could have simply said that the loan never happened. Since the lender cannot prove the existence of the loan, that claim would have prevailed. Therefore, the claim that the loan was repaid is believed as well. This is a classic Migu, although many cases of Migu exist to support a position in court.
Other cases in which Migu is invoked are cases in which witnesses might have a personal gain in testifying, which would normally disqualify the testimony. If another option can be found for the witnesses to achieve the same personal gain, some authorities rule that the testimony can be accepted.
==Exceptions to the rule== There are exceptions to the rule of Migu, perhaps the most common one is known as "Migu in the place of witnesses" (Hebrew מיגו במקום עדים). This takes on two meanings. The first is that in a case in which the claimant has irrefutable proof - such as valid witnesses - supporting his claim, the litigant cannot use Migu as a defense. The reasoning is that the witnesses are "stronger" than the Migu. (This means that in the order of acceptance of proofs and logic the court of law will rule based on the stronger proof/logic.) A second meaning to "Migu in the place of witnesses" is similar yet very different from the first. That is, when witnesses support the alternative claim, thereby destroying the litigant's position, as the litigant can no longer claim that if he was looking to win dishonestly he/she would have claimed the alternative. Because the alternative is no longer possible. This exception is true even if the witnesses bear testimony after the litigant made his/her claim. (see Rabbi Busel On Migu)
Another exception would be if the proposed alternative claim is considered to be an embarrassment to the defendant. Cases that would qualify are, if the story being told is embarrassing by its very nature, it is a highly unlikely story and a person would not be so brazen as to make the alternative claim (Hebrew, מיגו דהעזה לא אמרינן) or it is well known that the particular proposed fact is untrue, even if the claimant can't prove it. The logic behind this exception is elementary. The Migu lends credibility to the defendant by asking the question: "if he is lying in an effort to exempt himself from paying his dues, he should have told more believable lie". If the court can find a probable reason why he would avoid telling the harder-to-disprove story, then the entire logic falls apart.
A third rule in the non acception of Migu's is that "a Migu to extract is not said" (Hebrew מיגו להוציא לא אמרינן).<ref>Tosafis to Talmud, Baba metzia 2b</ref><ref>First Tosafis to Talmud, Bava Basra 32b</ref> This means that the logic of Migu will not be excepted on the claimants side. ("Why did he claim that the item used to belong to the possessing party and that he had bought it from him, he could have said that the item never belonged to the possessing party?"). The predominant reason for this is that the burden of proof is on the claimant (Hebrew המוציא מחבירו עליו הראיה) and therefore even though a defendant can avoid payment using the Migu as a defense, it is not sufficient proof for the claimant. Another point is that this would open endless opportunities for con men (Many Jewish laws are designed to make con games more difficult)This is the opinion of the Tosafists.The Ramban among other Rishonim disagree with this rule and contend that it is a valid reasoning. Some explain that the root of the question lays in understanding Migu's properties as a tool in court. The Tosafists felt that a Migu is a leverage tool (Hebrew, כח הטענה), meaning that if a person chose to make a less favorable claim over a more favorable one, he is given the benefit of the doubt, although he is not necessarily believed based on his Migu, therefore his Migu can only deflect charges but not charge others. The Ramban on the other hand felt that Migu provides proof of the legitimacy of the claim, it can therefore be used as an attack tool.
==Rabbi Busel on Migu== According to Rabbi Betzalel Busel there exists a fourth exception to the rule of Migu, and that is a stipulation that the potential claim be an alternative to the current claim and not an additional claim. ("I could have said something else instead", not "I could have added another point".) The reasoning given is that avoidinDHKH whereas giving an alternative claim gives the claim itself credence, and for a Migu to be effective it must be a boost for the claim and not for the person. (There is no rule to believe a more trustworthy person over a less trustworthy one, even though there is reason to believe one over the other.<ref>See Tosafis to Zevachim 103a</ref>) This goes against the ruling of many leading commentators.<ref>Shaar Mishpat</ref><ref>Ramban to Baba Basra 30a</ref><ref>Rashba ibid.</ref>
Rabbi Busel provides a rule of thumb in regards to Migu: No Migu can accomplish more than the alternative claim on which the Migu is based.<ref>Chidushi Harim</ref><ref>Rabbi Akivah Eiger to Baba Basra 31a</ref> The logic is that it would be unseemly to base the value of a claim on an alternative one and thereby give the actual claim greater power than the alternative. Also in most cases the greater power that the Migu has would be a logical reason for a dishonest litigant to make the Migu claim, which would in effect disqualify the Migu itself. (In most cases the Migu claim is in place of a claim that would be effective without a Migu, which is generally favored over a claim that requires a Migu to uphold it. In addition, a Migu is not completely believed; it is no more that a law that the Migu claim must be accepted by the court.) This explains why witnesses who come after the Migu claim is invoked and accepted, disqualify the Migu, even though the logic still exists (the litigant had no idea that the witnesses would come, and still he chose to use the weaker claim), because since the alternate claim would have been rejected at this point, the Migu may no longer operate.
Rabbi Busel made a general point, that to disqualify a Migu, any gain that can be achieved by making the current claim over the alternate one will suffice to disqualify the Migu. This includes a gain that most people would not lie for, which means that even a gain that would not create doubt about a claim would disqualify the Migu.

{{Orphan|date=March 2017}} '''Mydemocracy.ca''' is a public consultation commissioned by the [[Canadian federal government]]. It is intended to inform [[electoral reform]]. Replacing the existing [[first-past-the-post]] system with another [[voting system]], before the next election, was a [[Canadian federal election 2015|2015 election]] promise.[http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/canadian-politics/exclusive-trudeau-government-to-mail-every-household-in-canada-questions-on-electoral-reform Exclusive: Trudeau government to mail every household in Canada questions on electoral reform | National Post] ==Timeline== The consultation was first reported publicly in early November 2016, with notices arriving by mail at the beginning of December. The survey was originally scheduled to end on December 30, but has since been extended to '''January 15, 2017'''. A small pilot study (4,273 subjects) ran between October 23, 2016 and November 22, 2016. The pilot study does not seem to have been [[trial registration|registered]] or reported.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} ==Purpose== A government official described the consultation as neither a referendum, a survey, nor a poll. The MyDemocracy.ca FAQ calls it "...more than just a survey. MyDemocracy.ca is a public engagement and education platform."https://www.MyDemocracy.ca There have been calls for a referendum, as [http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?DocId=8655791&Language=E&Mode=1&Parl=42&Ses=1&File=408 recommended] in the [[Canadian House of Commons Special Committee on Electoral Reform]]'s [http://www.parl.gc.ca/Content/HOC/Committee/421/ERRE/Reports/RP8655791/421_ERRE_Rpt03_PDF/421_ERRE_Rpt03-e.pdf report].[http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/canadian-politics/house-of-commons-committee-recommends-referendum-on-electoral-reform Liberals call all-party electoral reform committee ‘radical’ and ‘hasty’ after it recommends referendum | National Post] ==Content== The website does not ask direct questions about subjects' preferences for specific [[voting systems]]. Instead, it asks about preferences for [[Voting system#Evaluating voting systems using criteria|features of electoral systems]]. No one voting system can have all features, so it explicitly asks about trade-offs. This approach has been criticized, particularly by proponents of proportional representation[http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/canadian-politics/dont-blame-electoral-reform-committee-for-ridiculous-survey-questions-enraged-mp-says Don’t blame electoral reform committee for ‘ridiculous’ survey questions, enraged MP says | National Post][http://news.nationalpost.com/full-comment/andrew-coyne-biggest-problem-with-mydemocracy-survey-is-the-questions Andrew Coyne: Biggest problem with MyDemocracy survey is the questions | National Post][http://www.fairvote.ca/includepr/ Fair Vote Canada respectfully asks Minister Monsef to include questions about the principle of proportional representation on the Survey to Canadians], November 24, 2016, with [[Fair Vote Canada]] publishing its own interpretations of the questions in terms of voting systems.[http://mycanadiandemocracy.ca/ This site will help you decipher the Government's new survey on electoral reform: the myths, the traps and the facts] MyDemocracy.ca uses answers to group the visitor into categories: *Guardians *Challengers *Pragmatists *Cooperators *Innovators These categories were derived from a [[pilot study]] of 4,273 Canadians over the age of 18. [[Weighted mean|Weighted data]] from the pilot study was used to created these five categories:
Latent [[cluster analysis|clusters]] were identified using a finite [[mixture model]], where the number of [[component analysis (statistics)|components]] was determined through a dissimilarity-based partitioning method. The mixture model itself was defined such that all within-component [[covariance matrices]] were assumed to be [[diagonal matrix|diagonal]], meaning that the [eight] constitutive factors were assumed to be locally [[statistically independent|independent]]. Cluster variances were set to have equal shape, volume and orientation (an "EEI" model). * [https://www.Mydemocracy.ca Mydemocracy.ca methodology]
==Other consultations== The consultation parallels other consultations. The all-party [[Canadian House of Commons Special Committee on Electoral Reform]] held country-wide consultations, which went into a December 1 [http://www.parl.gc.ca/Content/HOC/Committee/421/ERRE/Reports/RP8655791/421_ERRE_Rpt03_PDF/421_ERRE_Rpt03-e.pdf report].[http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/canadian-politics/nationwide-electoral-reform-survey-surprises-and-disappoints-trudeaus-political-opponents Nationwide electoral reform survey surprises many and disappoints some of Trudeau’s political opponents | National Post] These included consultations through [[members of parliament|MPs]], with MPs of all parties urged to hold townhall meetings with their constituents. Canadians were also urged to hold their own consultation meetings, and sent the results to the government; a [https://www.canada.ca/en/campaign/electoral-reform/participate-in-canadian-federal-electoral-reform-consultations/host-a-canadian-federal-electoral-reform-dialogue-in-your-community/step-5-host-your-canadian-federal-electoral-reform-dialogue/canadian-federal-electoral-reform-dialogue-hosting-guide.html Canadian federal electoral reform dialogue hosting guide] was released.[http://globalnews.ca/news/2809260/liberals-release-electoral-reform-toolkit-internet-releases-snark/ Liberals release electoral reform ‘toolkit,’ Internet releases snark - National | Globalnews.ca] ==Privacy and security== Information given on the site is covered under the [[Privacy Act (Canada)|Privacy Act]] and the [[Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act]]. The FAQ initially stated that people would not be counted unless they gave demographic information, such as household income. Complaints lead to a change in advertised study methodology. People who refuse to give demographic information will now be included in raw figures, but their response will not be weighted and extrapolated to other people with similar demographics[https://ipolitics.ca/2016/12/06/mydemocracy-ca-poses-privacy-risks-for-canadians-in-small-towns-professor/ Mydemocracy.ca poses privacy risks for Canadians in small towns: professor - U of Ottawa’s Michael Geist says demographic information could reveal users’ identity]. BJ Siekierski, Tuesday, December 6th, 2016[http://www.michaelgeist.ca/2016/12/mydemocracy-ca-response-doesnt-count-if-you-refuse-to-disclose-household-income-and-other-personal-information/ MyDemocracy.ca Responses Don't Count If You Refuse To Disclose Household Income and Other Personal Information - Michael Geist] While users are not required to give names, their postal code, profession, education, gender, age, language, and membership in certain groups is requested. This is more than enough information to identify a specific person from the data they submit; [[deanonymization]] has been demonstrated using only gender, age, and postal code.{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1111/j.1748-720X.1997.tb01885.x| issn = 1073-1105 |eissn = 1748-720X| volume = 25| issue = 2-3| pages = 98–110| last = Sweeney| first = Latanya| title = Weaving Technology and Policy Together to Maintain Confidentiality| journal = The Journal of Law, Medicine & Ethics| accessdate = 2017-01-04| date = June 1997| url = http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/j.1748-720X.1997.tb01885.x}} in [http://randomwalker.info/publications/no-silver-bullet-de-identification.pdf No silver bullet: De-identification still doesn't work], Arvind Narayanan and Edward W. Felten, July 9, 2014 The site also collects [[IP addresses]] and "information such as page requests, browser type, operating system, average time spent on the website, and pixel codes (i.e. which pages you visit on the website)". The possibility of people casting multiple votes has been raised, but Vox Pops Labs has methods they intend using to reject multiple votes. The survey was not run by [[Statistics Canada]], the arms-length Canadian government body that typically does surveys, but by Vox Pops Labs. The site is encrypted, with a [[public key certificate]] issued by [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]], to prevent [[man-in-the-middle attacks]]. It is hosted by [[GoDaddy]]. ==Costs== The cost of commissioning Vox Pop Labs to design and run the survey was initially estimated at CAN$250 000,[http://globalnews.ca/news/3106870/new-electoral-reform-tool-mydemocracy-ca-draws-fire-online/ New electoral reform tool mydemocracy.ca draws fire online - National | Globalnews.ca] but the final cost was $326 500.[http://www.macleans.ca/news/canada/the-making-of-mydemocracy-ca-the-liberals-electoral-reform-survey/ The making of MyDemocracy.ca, the Liberals' survey - Macleans.ca] The cost of the mail-out of 13 million postcards announcing the plan has not been released, but is estimated at ~CAN$2 million. The [[Elections Canada]] Chief Electoral Officer estimated the cost of a full referendum at CAN$300 million, and said that he would need to know by December 2016 if a vote was coming. However, he also said that there were possibilities for savings, such as a mail-in ballot, or holding the referendum at the same time as the next federal election, which could plausibly reduce the costs to less than 40 cents per voter (about $15 million).[http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?DocId=8655791&Language=E&Mode=1&Parl=42&Ses=1&File=390#117 House of Commons Committees - ERRE (42-1) - Strengthening Democracy in Canada : Principles, Process and Public Engagement for Electoral Reform - E. To Referendum or Not to Ref...] ==References== [[Category:Electoral reform in Canada]] [[Category:Canadian political media]] [[Category:Law reform]] [[Category:Survey methodology]] [[Category:Statistical data sets]]

The '''no-impeachment rule''' (also known as the '''non-impeachment rule''') is a rule in the [[procedural law]] of many jurisdictions. It says testimony from jurors about what occurred during [[jury deliberations]] may not be used to impeach a verdict during an [[appeal]]. The rule originated in [[common law]] and has been codified into statute in many jurisdictions. ==Definition== The United States [[Federal Rules of Evidence]], section 606(b)[https://www.law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_606 Federal Rules of Evidence Rule 606.] Legal Information Institute, Cornell School of Law defines it as:
(1) Prohibited Testimony or Other Evidence. During an inquiry into the validity of a verdict or indictment, a juror may not testify about any statement made or incident that occurred during the jury deliberations; the effect of anything on that juror’s or another juror’s vote; or any juror’s mental processes concerning the verdict or indictment. The Court may not receive a juror’s affidavit of evidence of a juror’s statement on these matters. (2) Exceptions. A juror may testify about whether: (A) extraneous prejudicial information was improperly brought to the jury’s attention; (B) an outside influence was improperly brought to bear on any juror; or (C) a mistake was made in entering the verdict on the verdict form.
==Variations== Under [[common law]], jurors were forbidden from impeaching their own verdict. Some states adopted a more limited version of the no-impeachment rule, known as the "Iowa rule" which "prevented jurors from testifying only about their own subjective beliefs, thoughts, or motives during deliberations."[https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/16pdf/15-606_886b.pdf Peña-Rodriguez v. Colorado]. United States Supreme Court ==Localities== The Federal rule has been adopted into the law of 42 jurisdictions. The Iowa rule has been adopted in 9 jurisdictions. ==Exceptions== The [[United States Supreme Court]] created a [[racial bias]] exception to the rule in their decision in ''[[Peña-Rodriguez v. Colorado]]'' (2017). ==See also== *''[[Tanner v. United States]]'' (1987) ==References== [[Category:Legal terminology]] [[Category:Legal procedure]] {{law-term-stub}}

revision.comment: Added reference to legislation, and improved reference for commissioners.
revision.text:
{{Infobox government agency |agency_name = Parades Commission |nativename = |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = Parades Commission (Northern Ireland) logo.gif |logo_width = 100px |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |picture = |picture_width = |picture_caption = |formed = {{Start date|1998||}} |preceding1 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Northern Ireland]] |headquarters = Windsor House, 9-15 Bedford Street, Belfast, BT2 7EL |chief1_name = [[Anne Henderson (Northern Ireland)|Anne Henderson]] |chief1_position = Chair |agency_type = [[Non-departmental public body]] |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |keydocument1 = |website = [http://www.paradescommission.org/ www.paradescommission.org/] |footnotes = |map = |map_width = |map_caption = }} The '''Parades Commission''' is a [[quasi-judicial body|quasi-judicial]] [[non-departmental public body]] responsible for placing restrictions on any [[parades in Northern Ireland]] it deems contentious or offensive. It is composed of seven members, all of whom are appointed by the [[Secretary of State for Northern Ireland]]. Restrictions it can impose include a prohibition on music being played, re-routing parades to avoid contentious areas, or banning certain participants based on previous breaches of its determinations. Its rulings are usually enforced by either parade stewards or the [[Police Service of Northern Ireland|police]], though there are disputes as to whether this is done to the [[letter and spirit of the law|letter of the law]] in certain areas. The Commission acts under the Public Processions (Northern Ireland) Act 1998.<ref>{{Cite legislation UK | type = act | year = 1998 | chapter = 2 | number = | act = Public Processions (Northern Ireland) Act 1998 }}</ref>
Parade organisers and participants are liable to arrest and prosecution for breaching any of the Commission's rulings, although no-one has been charged since the Commission was established in 1998.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} A section 6(7) offence has a maximum punishment of six months imprisonment or level five on the [[standard scale]].
The Commission was set up after the large-scale civil strife that followed the [[Drumcree conflict]] over an [[Orange Institution|Orange Order]] parade in [[Portadown]]. It has come under strong criticism from the Order. The Grand Lodge of the Order has a policy of non-engagement with the Commission, although some private and district lodges, particularly those with contentious parades, have agreed to talk to it.
==Commissioners== As of September 2018, the Commissioners are:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.paradescommission.org/About-Us/Commission.aspx|title=Commission - Northern Ireland Parades Commission|website=www.paradescommission.org|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref>
*[[Anne Henderson (Northern Ireland)|Anne Henderson]] (Chair) *[[Sarah Havlin]] *[[Colin Kennedy]] *[[France McCartney]] *[[Paul Hutchinson (Parades Commissioner)|Paul Hutchinson]]
==See also==
*[[List of Government departments and agencies in Northern Ireland]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.paradescommission.org/ Parades Commission]
{{Northern Ireland Office}}
