{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox organization |name = Piratbyrån |image = Piratbyrån.svg |alt = Piratbyrån's logotype. |formation = {{Start date|2003|08|01|df=y}} |extinction = {{End date|2010|06|22|df=y}} |type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] |status = Disbanded |purpose = [[Think tank]], opposition to [[intellectual property]] |language = [[Sweden|Swedish]] |website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20141224113603/http://piratbyran.org/ piratbyran.org (archived)] }} '''Piratbyrån''' ({{IPA-sv|pɪ²rɑːtbʏˌroːn|lang|Piratbyrån-pronunciation.ogg}} "The Pirate Bureau") was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] organization (or [[think tank]]) established to support the free sharing of information, culture, and [[intellectual property]]. Piratbyrån provided a counterpoint to [[lobby group]]s such as the Swedish [[Svenska antipiratbyrån|Anti-Piracy Bureau]]. In 2005 Piratbyrån released an [[anthology]] entitled ''Copy Me'',{{Cite book | author=Piratbyrån | title=Copy Me - Samlade Texter Från Piratbyrån | year=2005 | language=Swedish | url=https://archive.org/details/CopyMeSamladeTexterFranPiratbyran}} containing selected texts previously available from its website. Members of Piratbyrån participated in debates on Swedish Radio and Swedish Television and also gave several lectures in other European countries, such as at the 2005 22nd [[Chaos Communication Congress]] in Berlin.{{cite web |url= http://piratbyran.org/index.php?view=articles&id=107| title = Piratbyrån speech at Chaos Communication Congress 22C3 in Berlin|date=December 2005 |author=[[Palle Torsson]] and [[Rasmus Fleischer]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060206151626/http://www.piratbyran.org/index.php?view=articles&id=107 |archivedate=6 February 2006 |accessdate=15 July 2010}} Piratbyrån's activities might have changed over the years, partly as a result of the addition of the [[Pirate Party (Sweden)|Pirate Party]] to the Swedish political scene. During [[Walpurgis Night]] 2007, Piratbyrån burned all of their remaining copies of ''Copy Me'' in a ritual-like performance, declaring:
The file-sharing debate is hereby buried. When we talk about file-sharing from now on it's as one of many ways to copy. We talk about better and worse ways of indexing, archiving and copying—not whether copying is right or wrong. Winter is pouring down the hillside. Make way for spring![http://piratbyran.org/walpurgis/ Walpurgis] Piratbyran. Retrieved 16 July 2010.
Jonas Andersson, a Swedish researcher specialized in the politics of [[file-sharing]], gave this brief definition in October 2009:
Piratbyrån is entirely separate from The Pirate Party; it is more of a loosely organised think-tank, a website, a philosophical greenhouse or FAQ guide to digitization.Andersson, Jonas (13 October 2009). [http://liquidculture.wordpress.com/2009/10/13/qa-re-pirate-politics/ Q&A re Pirate Politics] ''liquidculture notebook'' (Blog).
The [[MPAA]]-funded Svenska [[Svenska antipiratbyrån|Antipiratbyrån]] (Swedish Anti-Piracy Bureau), an agency devoted to fighting copyright infringement, was formed in 2001, before Piratbyrån. Piratbyrån humorously copied the name of their opponent, removing the "anti".Ernesto (23 June 2010). [http://torrentfreak.com/pirate-bays-founding-group-piratbyran-disbands-100623/ "Pirate Bay’s Founding Group ‘Piratbyrån’ Disbands"] Retrieved 23 June 2010. In June 2010 the group disbanded following the death of co-founder and prominent member [[Ibrahim Botani]], also known as Ibi Kopimi Botani.{{Cite web | first=Ibrahim | last=Botani | title=Untitled blog | website=Botanibladet | date=19 June 2008 | url=http://botanibladet.blogspot.nl/2008/06/botanibladets-ppnande.html}} Several former members of Piratbyrån are now involved in [[Telecomix]]. The front page of the website was replaced with the three words {{lang|se|Stängt för eftertanke}} (Swedish for ''Closed for reflection'').{{cite web |url=http://www.piratbyran.org/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2004-10-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041001003858/http://www.piratbyran.org/ |archivedate=2004-10-01 |df= }} ==Self-definition== In 2008 Piratbyrån published a report titled ''Piratbyrån - The Bureau of Piracy Activities 2007'' which starts with the following description of the organisation: {{quote|Piratbyrån (The Bureau of Piracy) is not an organization, at least not primarily. First and foremost, Piratbyrån is since its beginning in 2003 an ongoing conversation. We are reflecting over questions regarding copying, information infrastructure and digital culture. Within the group, using our own different experiences and skills, as in our daily encounters with other people. These conversations often bring about different kinds of activities.|{{cite web |url= http://piratbyran.org/PBverksamhet2007/PB%20activities%202007%20(text%20only).pdf|format=PDF| title = Piratbyrån – The Bureau of Piracy Activities 2007| year=2008}}}} ==Definition by Prix Ars Electronica jury== As Piratbyrån received an "award of distinction" at [[Prix Ars Electronica]] in 2009,oso (9 September 2009). [http://el-oso.net/blog/archives/2009/09/09/ars-electronica-digital-communities-forum/ |Ars Electronica| Communities Forum] El-Oso.net.[http://www.aec.at/prix_history_en.php?year=2009 History of Prix Ars Electronica / 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101025084014/http://aec.at/prix_history_en.php?year=2009 |date=2010-10-25 }} Ars Electronica, 2009. Retrieved 17 July 2010. the jury statement said: {{quote|Piratbyrån is not an organization but an on-going conversation on copyright, file-sharing and digital culture. Over the last six years Piratbyrån has been able to create a discursive space that enables individual and collective actors to be heard, and to significantly expand the range of opinions entering the public debate regarding copyright. To advance this conversation, they have been using a wide range of innovative, experimental, often humorous techniques – as well as traditional means such as public discussions, interviews and publications. The resulting debate has been multi-layered ranging from the technological (e.g. The Pirate Bay) to the artistic (e.g. a bus tour through Europe to Manifesta 08) to the political (e.g. Pirate Party). With very limited resources, Piratbyrån has been able to galvanize a political movement that has already shaped the development of digital culture and public policy in Sweden and across Europe, pushing the boundaries of the possible. Piratbyrån aims at nothing less than to fundamentally question the most basic categories – e.g. the distinction between the producer and the consumer – through which we understand culture in order to investigate if and how these apply to the digital condition. Piratbyrån does not claim to offer a solution to this extremely complex issue; indeed, it questions the assumption that copyright offers a one-size-fits all solution to cultural production, which now needs to be replaced with another unified solution. All of this has been done with great dedication and under considerable personal risk, yet they never forget that humor and irony are among the strongest weapons available to cultural producers.|Fleischer, Rasmus (17 September 2009). [http://copyriot.se/2009/09/17/ars-electronica-xi-definition-of-piratbyran/ Ars Electronica, XI: Definition of Piratbyrån] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090925150951/http://copyriot.se/2009/09/17/ars-electronica-xi-definition-of-piratbyran/ |date=2009-09-25 }} Copyriot.se] Quote of David Sasaki. Retrieved 17 July 2010.}} ==BitTorrent tracker== {{wikinews|The Pirate Bay and Piratbyrån raided}} [[Image:Rasmus Fleischer.jpg|right|thumb|[[Rasmus Fleischer]], spokesman of Piratbyrån speaking at a demonstration in [[Stockholm]] held 3 June 2006.]] Members of Piratbyrån founded the [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]] tracker [[The Pirate Bay]] in 2003 as a Swedish language site. The Pirate Bay now operates independently from Piratbyrån, although a number of The Pirate Bay administrators were also active in Piratbyrån.{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2006/03/70358 |last=Harrison |first=Ann |title=The Pirate Bay: Here to Stay? |publisher=Wired |date=13 March 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031053808/http://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2006/03/70358 |archivedate=31 October 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.slyck.com/story819_Slyck_Interviews_The_Pirate_Bay| last=Ingram | first=Michael | title=Slyck Interviews The Pirate Bay| publisher=[[Slyck.com]] |date=7 June 2005}} ===Police raid=== On the morning of 31 May 2006, the servers of both [[The Pirate Bay]], a popular Swedish [[BitTorrent tracker]], and Piratbyrån were confiscated in a raid by Swedish police. The seizure was part of investigation into possible illegal activities on the part of The Pirate Bay. Piratbyrån and the Antipiratbyrån set up a temporary news blog during the investigation.{{cite web |url= http://piratbyran.blogspot.com/| title = Piratbyrån Blog |accessdate=25 July 2008}}{{cite web|url= http://www.antipiratbyran.com/index.htm?id=news&p=p19#19|title= Antipiratbyrån Blog|accessdate= 25 July 2008|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080806101720/http://www.antipiratbyran.com/index.htm?id=news&p=p19#19|archivedate= 6 August 2008|df= }} ==Activities in 2007== In ''Piratbyrån - The Bureau of Piracy Activities 2007'', published in 2008, Piratbyrån list its activities for the year 2007. Activities by Piratbyrån members include lectures at universities and conferences, the publication of reports, participation in art projects and research projects, an interview with [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] in February 2007, participation in the planning of [[The Oil of the 21st Century]] conference in Berlin, presentations at a Norwegian computer party (The Gathering), interviews to the media regarding the raid on [[The Pirate Bay]], opening of a webshop to sell Kopimi Klothing, participation in the organisation of protests to mark the one-year anniversary of the police raid on [[The Pirate Bay]], attendance of the BELEF07 festival in [[Belgrade]] ([[Serbia]]), and participation in the organisation of a one-day art event in [[Stockholm]] titled "Who Makes And Owns Your Work". In March 2007 Piratbyrån members were invited to a meeting with the executive group for the [[Swedish Film Institute]], to share their views about film and copying. According to Piratbyrån "The leadership listens with interest — only to some months later launch new anti-piracy initiatives...". In the same month Piratbyrån collaborates with the [[Norway|Norwegian]] group [[Piratgruppen]], launching the counter-campaign "Piracy frees music" (promoted via [[The Pirate Bay]]), in response to the "Piracy kills music" anti-piracy campaign by the Norwegian record industry. In 2007 members of Piratbyrån also contributed to the production of the film ''[[Steal This Film|Steal This Film (Part Two)]]'', which features interviews with Piratbyrån members and was released in December 2007. ==Activities in 2009== Piratbyrån organized the "Spectrial", a theatricalizing intervention in [[The Pirate Bay trial]] in Stockholm, early in 2009.[http://trial.thepiratebay.org/ The Pirate Bay Trial website]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306020910/http://trial.thepiratebay.org/ |date=6 March 2009 }}{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} Installed the Embassy of Piracy [https://web.archive.org/web/20090917041835/http://embassyofpiracy.org/ - The Embassy of Piracy], for the First Internet Pavilion at the [[Venice Biennial]]Aman, Jan (September 2009). [http://www.blay.se/files/eop.pdf "In at the Deep End"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100813173437/http://www.blay.se/files/eop.pdf |date=2010-08-13 }} (PDF). [[Dazed & Confused (magazine)|Dazed & Confused]]. At the [[Prix Ars Electronica]] Piratbyrån received an "award of distinction" (including a prize money of 5000 euro) in the category "Digital Communities". The motivation of the jury underlined the Piratbyrån "never forget that humor and irony are among the strongest weapons available to cultural producers." ==Kopimi== {{Multiple image | image1=Kopimi_pyra2.svg | width1=200 | image2=Kopimi k.svg | width2=96 | footer=Two Kopimi symbols, one with pyramid and one without. More variations can be found on [https://www.kopimi.com/ www.kopimi.com] and [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Kopimi_logos on Commons]. }} The '''Kopimi''' symbol, also spelled '''kopimi''', was conceived in January 2005 by Piratbyrån co-founder [[Ibrahim Botani]]. The logo, pronounced "copy me", can be used to specifically request people to copy and distribute a work, for any purpose. Botani intended the logo to be the opposite of copyright, which usually restricts copying a work, and as a unifying symbol of the [[Opposition to copyright|anti-copyright]] ideas Piratbyrån stood for.{{Cite web | first=Rasmus | last=Fleischer | title=Ibi Kopimi Botani | date=23 June 2010 | website=Copyriot | url=http://copyriot.se/2010/06/23/ibi-kopimi-botani/}} As such, Kopimi may be considered an [[anti-copyright notice]] of sorts. Later in 2005, the Kopimi logotype was included in the Piratbyrån book ''Copy Me''.Piratbyrån (2005). pp. 153, 154, 160, 164. It was also put on the front page of [[The Pirate Bay]], where it remains until this day. The history section of the site stated: "''Some of you may have noticed that little symbol at the bottom of the page, the pyramid. It's a symbol called Kopimi (Copy Me) which was founded by an old friend of ours, the artist Ibi Botani. It's basically about promoting copying. Using the kopimi symbol on something not only shows that it is ok to copy it, it says it wants to be copied, mixed or manipulated!''"{{Cite web | author=Unknown | title=History of 2007 | url=http://thepiratebay.org/history/2007 | website=thepiratebay.org | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201011954/http://thepiratebay.org/history/2007 | archive-date=1 February 2009 | dead-url=yes}} While Kopimi may appear to be a radical [[List of free content licenses|free content license]], in effect similar to [[Creative Commons license#Zero / public domain|Creative Commons Zero]], no one associated with Piratbyrån ever called Kopimi a license, instead describing it as a symbol of certain ideas. The website of Kopimi contains no terms or legal text. The [[Open Source Initiative]], [[Free Software Foundation]], or any other organisation within the [[open-source movement]], does not list Kopimi as an approved license.{{Cite web | author=Open Source Initiative | title=Licenses by Name | website=Opensource.org | url=http://opensource.org/licenses/alphabetical}}{{Cite web | author=Free Software Foundation | title=Various Licenses and Comments about Them | website=gnu.org | url=https://www.gnu.org/licenses/license-list.html}} [[Wikimedia Commons]], a repository of free content and a sister site of Wikipedia, allows users to label their files with Kopimi.{{Cite web | author=– | title=Pages that link to "Template:Kopimi" | website=Wikimedia Commons | url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:WhatLinksHere/Template:Kopimi&hidelinks=1}} ===Kopimism=== {{Main article|Missionary Church of Kopimism}} '''Kopimism''' and '''kopimist(s)''' are terms derived from Botani's symbol. It is unclear who coined them, but they have been used since at least July 2006.{{Cite web | author=The Pirate Bay | title=TPB announces its support for ACFI against Ladonia | date=25 July 2006 | website=thepiratebay.org | url=http://thepiratebay.org/blog.php?id=34 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070323072858/http://thepiratebay.org/blog.php?id=34 | archivedate=23 March 2007 | dead-url=yes}}{{Cite web | author=Unknown | title=How the Kopimists Conquered Internets – and Launched a War | date=25 July 2006 | website=Solidarity with Ladonia! Stop the dirty war! | url=http://no-war-against-ladonia.blogspot.nl/2006/07/how-kopimists-conquered-internets-and.html}} In January 2007, the Pirate Bay used the terms when they attempted (unsuccessfully) to buy [[Principality of Sealand|Sealand]], a large sea fort off the coast of England and a self-proclaimed country. The Pirate Bay declared: "''To make sure the owners will be kopimistic and that the country won’t be governed by people that do not care about its future, we have come up with a plan. With the help of all the kopimists on Internets, we want to buy Sealand.''"{{Cite web | author=The Pirate Bay | title=Buy Sealand | url=http://buysealand.com/ | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070126211851/http://buysealand.com/ | archivedate=2007-01-26 | dead-url=yes}}{{Cite web | first=Tuan | last=Nguyen | title=PirateBay.org Wants to Be Own Country | website=[[DailyTech]] | url=http://www.dailytech.com/PirateBayorg+Wants+to+Be+Own+Country/article5692.htm}} The [[Missionary Church of Kopimism]] was founded in 2010 by Isak Gerson, a philosophy student and a member of the [[Pirate Party of Sweden]]. After two failed attempts, Kopimism was officially recognized as a religion by the Swedish government in January 2012. The Church considers copying a holy virtue, and uses various Kopimi symbols to present itself.{{Cite web | author=Ernesto | title=File-sharing recognized as official religion in Sweden | date=4 January 2012 | website=[[TorrentFreak]] | url=https://torrentfreak.com/file-sharing-recognized-as-official-religion-in-sweden-120104/}}{{Cite web | first=Rolle | last=Romig | title=The First Church of Pirate Bay | website=[[The New Yorker]] | date=12 January 2012 | url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-first-church-of-pirate-bay}} ===Copie=== [[File:Copie.svg|thumb|150px|Copie logo]] Inspired by Kopimi, the [[Pirate Party of Brazil]] created their own version of the concept called "Copie", which plays both on the Portuguese words "copie" (meaning copy) and "co-pie" (meaning tweet together). The Copie logo shows 5 birds tweeting together.[http://www.partidopirata.org/copie PartidoPirata] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090707074649/http://www.partidopirata.org/copie |date=2009-07-07 }} Brazilian Pirate Party website. Retrieved 17 July 2010. ==See also== * [[Anti-copyright]] * [[Copyleft]] * [[Missionary Church of Kopimism]] * [[Pirate Party]] (''Piratpartiet'') (not affiliated with Piratbyrån) * [[The Pirate Bay]] A bittorrent site. * ''[[Steal This Film]]'' * [[Telecomix]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Piratbyrån}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20141224113603/http://piratbyran.org/ Official website (archived)] * [http://www.kopimi.com/ Kopimi] * [http://www.piratgruppen.org/ Piratgruppen.org] - Danish sister organization * [http://www.artliberated.org/ Art Liberated] - Another project from Piratbyrån, highlighting [[remix culture]] and opposing [[censorship]] of art. * [http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=04/05/02/0044257 Slashdot on Piratbyrån's May Day Demonstration 2004] * [http://amsterdam.nettime.org/Lists-Archives/nettime-l-0505/msg00006.html Press release about Piratbyrån's May Day Demonstration 2005] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060211011453/http://www.flackattack.org/faw/index.php?title=The_Grey_Commons The Grey Commons, strategic considerations in the copyfight] Text by Piratbyrån's [[Palle Torsson]] and [[Rasmus Fleischer]], presenting the activities of 2005. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060612211234/http://www2.piratpartiet.se/nyheter/the_pirate_bay_and_piratbyran_taken_down_by_police The Pirate Bay and Piratbyrån taken down by Police] * [http://copyriot.wordpress.com/2006/12/12/between-artworks-and-networks/ Between artworks and networks: Navigating through the crisis of copyright] Theoretical lecture by Piratbyrån's [[Rasmus Fleischer]]. * [http://fadetogrey.wordpress.com/2006/10/14/brno/ Presentation of Piratbyrån by Magnus Eriksson], from the [[Bzoom]] festival in [[Brno]], October 2006. {{Intellectual property activism}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Piratbyran}} [[Category:2003 establishments in Sweden]] [[Category:2010 disestablishments in Sweden]] [[Category:Think tanks established in 2003]] [[Category:Think tanks disestablished in 2010]] [[Category:Intellectual property activism]] [[Category:Politics of Sweden]] [[Category:Political and economic think tanks based in Europe]] [[Category:Science and technology think tanks]] [[Category:Think tanks based in Sweden]] [[Category:Hacker culture]] [[Category:Open content]]

The '''Police (Scotland) Act 1956''' was an Act of the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]].
Except for s.37, the whole Act was repealed by the [[Police (Scotland) Act 1967]].

revision.comment: /* See also */ added template {{Historical left-wing third party presidential tickets (U.S.)}}
revision.text:
{{about|the 1924 Progressive Party||Progressive Party (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox political party | colorcode = {{Progressive Party (United States)/meta/color}} |name = Progressive Party | leader1_title = Chairmen | leader1_name = [[Robert M. La Follette Sr.]]
{{small|(1924–1925)}}
[[Robert M. La Follette Jr.]]
{{small|(1925–1934)}} | foundation = {{Start date|1924}} | dissolution = {{End date and age|1934}} | split = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] | successor = [[Wisconsin Progressive Party]] | headquarters = [[Washington, D.C.]] | ideology = [[Agrarianism]]
[[Populism]]
[[Progressivism in the United States|Progressivism]] | position = [[Centre-left politics|Center-left]] to [[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] | international = None | colors = {{Color box|{{Progressive Party (United States)/meta/color}}|border=darkgray}} [[Green]] | country = United States }} The '''Progressive Party''' of 1924 was a new party created as a vehicle for [[Robert M. La Follette, Sr.]] to run for president in the [[United States presidential election, 1924|1924 election]]. It did not run candidates for other offices, and it disappeared after the election. The party advocated [[progressivism in the United States|progressive]] positions such as government ownership of railroads and electric utilities, cheap credit for farmers, the outlawing of [[child labour|child labor]], stronger laws to help [[trade union|labor union]]s, more protection of civil liberties, an end to [[American imperialism]] in [[Latin America]], and a [[referendum]] before any president could lead the nation into war. After winning election to the [[United States Senate]] in 1905, La Follette had emerged as a leader of progressives. He sought the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] presidential nomination in the [[United States presidential election, 1912|1912 election]], but many of his backers switched to [[Theodore Roosevelt]] after the former president entered the race. La Follette refused to join Roosevelt's [[Progressive Party (United States, 1912)|Progressive Party]], and that party collapsed after 1916. However, the progressives remained a potent force within both major parties. In 1924, La Follette and his followers created their own Progressive Party which challenged the conservative major party nominees, [[Calvin Coolidge]] of the Republican Party and [[John W. Davis]] of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]. The Progressive Party was composed of La Follette supporters, who were distinguished from the earlier Roosevelt supporters by being generally more agrarian, populist, and midwestern in perspective, as opposed to urban, elite, and eastern. The party held a [[Nomination of Robert M. La Follette for President, 1924|national convention]] in July 1924 that nominated a ticket consisting of La Follette for president, and La Follete later selected Democratic Senator [[Burton K. Wheeler]] of [[Montana]] as his running mate. The ticket enjoyed support among many farmers and laborers and was endorsed by the [[Socialist Party of America]] and the [[American Federation of Labor]]. In the 1924 election, the party carried only La Follette's home state of [[Wisconsin]]. The ticket won 16.6% of the national popular vote and carried many counties in the Midwest and West with large [[German American]] elements or strong labor union movements.See: K.C. MacKay, ''The Progressive Movement of 1924.'' New York: Columbia University Press, 1947. The party's share of the vote represents one of the best [[List of third party performances in United States presidential elections|performances by a third party]] in presidential election history. After the election, La Follette continued to serve as a Republican Senator until his death in 1925. After his death, La Follette's family founded the [[Wisconsin Progressive Party]] and briefly dominated Wisconsin politics. == Wisconsin Progressives == [[File:1924prescountymap.PNG|thumb|right|400px|'''1924 Presidential election results by county.'''{{legend|#E32636|[[Calvin Coolidge]]|border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|#1560BD|[[John William Davis|John W. Davis]]|border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|#00A550|[[Robert M. La Follette, Sr.|Robert M. La Follette]]|border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} — light = plurality, green = over 50%]] Years before, La Follette had created the "Progressive" faction inside the [[Republican Party of Wisconsin]] in 1900. In 1912 he attempted to create a [[Progressive Party (United States, 1912)|Progressive Party]] but lost control to [[Theodore Roosevelt]], who became his bitter enemy.Nancy Unger, ''Fighting Bob La Follette: The Righteous Reformer.'' Second edition. Madison: Wisconsin Historical Society Press, 2008; pp. 221-238. In 1924 his new party (using the old 1912 name) called for public ownership of railroads, which catered to the [[Railroad brotherhoods]]. La Follette ran with Senator [[Burton K. Wheeler]], Democratic Senator from [[History of Montana|Montana]]. The party represented a farmer/labor coalition and was endorsed by the [[Socialist Party of America]], the [[American Federation of Labor]] and many railroad brotherhoods. The party did not run candidates for other offices, and only carried one state, Wisconsin. La Follette continued to serve in the Senate as a Republican until his death the following year, and was succeeded in a special election in 1925 by his son, [[Robert M. La Follette, Jr.]]Unger, ''Fighting Bob La Follette,'' pp. 281-303. The La Follette family continued his political legacy in Wisconsin, publishing ''[[The Progressive]]'' magazine and pushing for liberal reforms. In 1934, La Follette's two sons began the [[Wisconsin Progressive Party]], which briefly held power in the state and was for some time one of the state's major parties, often ahead of the Democrats.Herbert F. Margulies; ''The Decline of the Progressive Movement in Wisconsin, 1890-1920.'' (State Historical Society of Wisconsin, 1968.) == California Progressives == [[Hiram W. Johnson]], backed by suffragette and early feminist [[Katherine Philips Edson]],{{cite web|last=Braitman|first=Jacqueline R.|title=A California Stateswoman: The Public Career of Katherine Philips Edson|jstor=25158366|work=California History|pages=82–95|date=June 1986}} was a candidate for California governor in 1910, the Progressive Party vice presidential nominee in 1912, and was reelected as [[Governor of California]] on the Progressive ticket in [[California gubernatorial election, 1914|1914]]. In 1916, he was elected as a Progressive to the U.S. Senate and continued his affiliation with the state party throughout his decades in the Senate, while simultaneously winning the Republican nomination. While Johnson was personally close to Theodore Roosevelt, he was much closer ideologically to Robert La Follette. Johnson sat out the general election in 1924 after unsuccessfully challenging President [[Calvin Coolidge]] for the Republican nomination. Johnson personally disliked La Follette but grudgingly admired his quixotic third-party bid and generally agreed with his 1924 platform.See: George E. Mowry, ''The California Progressives.'' (1963). In 1934, when the La Follettes founded the [[Wisconsin Progressive Party]], the [[California Progressive Party]] obtained a ballot line in California and ran seven candidates (all unsuccessful, although [[Raymond L. Haight]] got 13% of the vote for [[Governor of California]], running as a moderate against socialist and Democratic nominee [[Upton Sinclair]]). In 1936 they elected [[Franck R. Havenner]] as [[United States House of Representatives|Congressman]] for [[California's 4th congressional district]], and garnered a significant portion of the votes in some other races. Havenner became a Democrat before the 1938 race; Haight defeated eventual winner [[Culbert Olson]] in the Progressive primary election, but received only 2.43% of the vote in the general election as a Progressive; and by the time of the 1942 gubernatorial election, the Progressives were no longer on the California ballot. By 1944, Haight was again a Republican, a delegate to the [[1944 Republican National Convention|Republican National Convention]].Kevin Starr, ''Endangered Dreams: The Great Depression in California.'' New York: Oxford University Press, 1996; pg. 152-154. === Presidential candidate performance === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Pres. candidate / [[Vice President of the United States|VP]] ! Popular votes ! Percentage ! [[Electoral College (United States)|Electoral votes]] |- | [[United States presidential election, 1924|1924]] || [[Robert M. La Follette Sr.]] / [[Burton K. Wheeler]] | style="text-align:right"| 4,831,706 #3 || 16.6% || 13 |} ==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * Hesseltine, William B. ''The Rise and Fall of Third Parties: From Anti-Masonry to Wallace''. Washington, DC: Public Affairs Press, 1948. * La Follette, Philip. ''Adventure in Politics: The Memoirs of Philip La Follette.'' New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston, 1970. * MacKay, K. C. ''The Progressive Movement of 1924''. New York: Columbia University Press, 1947. * Margulies, Herbert F. ''[https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&d=96272178 The Decline of the Progressive Movement in Wisconsin, 1890-1920]''. Madison, WI: State Historical Society of Wisconsin, 1968. * [[Russel B. Nye|Nye, Russel B.]], ''Midwestern Progressive Politics: A Historical Study of Its Origins and Development, 1870-1958''. Lansing: Michigan State College Press, 1951. * Unger, Nancy C. ''Fighting Bob La Follette: The Righteous Reformer''. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 2000. ==See also== * [[Progressive Party (United States, 1912)]] * [[Progressive Party (United States, 1948)]] * [[Nomination of Robert M. La Follette for President, 1924]] * [[A.J. Barnes]], California Progressive candidate {{United States presidential election, 1924}} {{Socialist Party of America}} {{United States political parties}} {{Historical left-wing third party presidential tickets (U.S.)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Progressive Party (United States, 1924-34)}} [[Category:1924 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Left-wing populism in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct progressive parties in the United States| ]] [[Category:Defunct democratic socialist parties in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct social democratic parties in the United States]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1924]] [[Category:Politics of California]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1946]] [[Category:Political history of Wisconsin]] [[Category:Political schisms]] [[Category:Progressive Era in the United States]] [[Category:1946 disestablishments in the United States]]

A '''public access file''' (sometimes capitalized as '''Public Access File''', sometimes abbreviated as '''PAF''', and also called a '''public examination file''') is a file that needs to be maintained by any United States employer hiring people in [[H-1B visa|H-1B]], [[H-1B1 visa|H-1B1]], or [[E-3 visa|E-3]] temporary nonimmigrant worker statuses. It is intended to include more background information related to the attestations made on the [[Labor Condition Application]] used for the [[Form I-129]] and/or visa application that was used to acquire the nonimmigrant worker status. The file may be requested by any member of the public through telephone or email inquiries, that should be responded to within 3 business days. It is distinguished from a private access file that contains more sensitive and confidential employee data that must be shared with the [[U.S. Department of Labor]] if they choose to investigate. Regulations governing the public access file can be found in the [[Code of Federal Regulations]], Title 20 (Employee Benefits), or more specifically, in 20 CFR 655.760<ref name=cfr>{{cite web|url = https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/20/655.760|title = 20 CFR 655.760 - What records are to be made available to the public, and what records are to be retained?|publisher = [[Code of Federal Regulations]] (mirrored on the website of the [[Legal Information Institute]])}}</ref> (note that that section does not itself use the term "public access file" but other sections that refer to it refer to it with that name).<ref name=cfr-h-1b-dependent-willful>{{cite web|url = https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/20/655.736|title = 20 CFR 655.736 - What are H-1B-dependent employers and willful violators?|publisher = [[Code of Federal Regulations]] (mirrored on the website of the [[Legal Information Institute]])|accessdate = June 12, 2016}}</ref>
== Contents of the file ==
We use the term "public access file" to refer to all the records associated with a specific LCA. In other words, to each LCA, there is one associated public access file, and different LCAs have different public access files. This holds even though much of the content of these files overlaps.<ref name=cfr/>
=== The Labor Condition Application itself ===
For LCAs submitted by paper, a copy of the certified LCA (Form ETA 9035E or Form ETA 9035) and cover pages (Form ETA 9035CP) must be included. If the LCA is submitted electronically, a printout of the certified application, signed by the employer, needs to be included.<ref name=cfr/><ref name=dol-summary>{{cite web|url = https://www.dol.gov/whd/immigration/h1bprsnt.ppt|title = The Employment of Non-immigrants on H-1B Visas (PPT)|publisher = [[United States Department of Labor]]|accessdate = June 12, 2016}}</ref>
=== Background information on the attestations made ===
The goal of the public access file is to provide more information explaining the basis of the attestations made in the [[Labor Condition Application]]. Below, we go over the list of the attestations made and any information that must be included in the public access file for those attestations.
==== Attestation #1: Wages ====
In the LCA, the employer must specify the wage that the non-immigrant worker(s) being hired via the LCA will be paid, and attest that the non-immigrant workers on behalf of whom the application is being made will be paid at or above both these numbers:
* The '''actual wage''': This is the wage paid to other employees in the company who do the same work. * The [[prevailing wage]]: This is the wage for that occupation in the geographical area of intended employment.
The employer must make similar attestation regarding non-wage benefits offered.
The public access file must contain four pieces of information relevant to the wage attestations:<ref name=cfr/><ref name=dol-summary/>
* Documentation of the wage rate being paid to the non-immigrant worker(s). * A full, clear explanation of the system the employer used to set the "actual wage" the employer has paid or will pay workers in the occupation for which the non-immigrant worker(s) is/are being sought. This should also include information on any periodic increases that the system may provide, such as a memorandum summarizing the employer's pay system or scale. Payroll records are not required in the ''public'' access file, but may be demanded by the Department of Labor in an audit. * A full, clear explanation of the system the employer used to set the "prevailing wage" for the occupation in the intended area of employment. A general description of the source and methodolofy suffices. The underlying individual wage data relied upon is not a matter of public record, but may be demanded by the Department of Labor in an audit. * A summary of benefits offered, as well as a statement on how differentiation in benefits is made when not all employees are offered or receive the same benefits. Where applicable, a statement that some/all of the non-immigrant workers are receiving home country benefits.<ref name=cfr/><ref name=cfr-lca-1>{{cite web|url = https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/20/655.731#c_3|title = 20 CFR 655.731 - What is the first LCA requirement, regarding wages?|accessdate = June 12, 2016|publisher = [[Code of Federal Regulations]] (mirrored on the [[Legal Information Institute]] website)}}</ref> The clause on benefits, along with the exception for home country benefits, was introduced as part of the [[American Competitiveness in the 21st Century Act]].
==== Attestation #2: Working conditions ====
In the LCA, the employer must attest that the hiring of non-immigrant workers will not adversely affect the working conditions of similarly employed workers at the company, and that the non-immigrant workers will be offered similar working conditions as native US workers. The official regulations on the public access file do not mention any information that needs to be included regarding working conditions.<ref name=cfr/>
==== Attestation #3: Strike, lockout, or work stoppage ====
In the LCA, the employer must attest that on the day the application is filed, there is not a strike, lockout, or work stoppage in the named occupation at the place of employment and that, if such a strike, lockout, or work stoppage occurs after the application is submitted, the employer will notify ETA within three (3) days of such occurrence and the application will not be used to file a work authorization petition until the ETA has determined that the work stoppage has ceased.
The official regulations on the public access file do not mention any information that needs to be included regarding strikes, lockouts, or work stoppages.<ref name=cfr/>
==== Attestation #4: Notice ====
In the LCA, the employer must attest that as of the date of application, notice of the application has been or will be provided both to workers within the company in the said application. Also, the (prospective) workers on whose behalf the application is filed must be provided a copy of the application.
The public access file must include proof of satisfying union/employee notification requirements.<ref name=cfr/><ref name=cfr-lca-4>{{cite web|url = https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/20/655.734|title = 20 CFR 655.734 - What is the fourth LCA requirement, regarding notice?|accessdate = June 12, 2016|publisher = [[Code of Federal Regulations]] (mirrored on the [[Legal Information Institute]] website)}}</ref> For non-union positions this means the posting notice.<ref name=dol-summary/><ref name=cfr-lca-4/>
The employer must maintain additional evidence that the LCA was posted for at least ten business days (about two weeks) in two conspicuous locations. This evidence need only be included in the private access file.
=== Requirements surrounding change in corporate structure ===
When the employer undergoes a change in corporate structure, the public access file must be amended to include a sworn statement by a responsible official of the new employing entity that it accepts all obligations, liabilities and undertakings under the LCAs filed by the predecessor employing entity, together with a list of each affected LCA and its date of certification, and a description of the actual wage system and FEIN of the new employing entity.<ref name=cfr/><ref name=dol-summary/>
=== Requirements relevant to H-1B-dependent employers and willful violators ===
The following are relevant to [[H-1B-dependent employer|H-1B-dependency]]. Employers who are H-1B-dependent, or who come close to being H-1B-dependent, may have some of these apply:<ref name=cfr/><ref name=cfr-h-1b-dependent-willful/><ref name=dol-summary/>
* Where the employer utilizes the definition of "single employer" in the IRC, a list of any entities included as part of the single employer in making the determination as to its H-1B-dependency status. * Where the employer is H-1B-dependent and/or a willful violator, and indicates on the LCA(s) that only "exempt" H-1B nonimmigrants will be employed, a list of such "exempt" H-1B nonimmigrants. * Where the employer is H-1B-dependent or a willful violator, a summary of the recruitment methods used and the time frames of recruitment of U.S. workers (or copies of pertinent documents showing this information). This helps provide substantiation of the additional attestations regarding recruitment and hiring that H-1B-dependent employers and willful violators need to make.
== Retention requirements ==
The PAF must be kept as long as the worker is employed in a status that depends on the corresponding LCA, and for one year after the worker is no longer in that status with the company. This one-year requirement pertains only to public access files; payroll records (that need to be maintained privately for a Department of Labor audit) need to be maintained for three years since the payment was made.<ref name=cfr/>
== Compliance burden and penalties ==
The employer must provide the public access file of any employee to any member of the public who requests it by phone or email. The turnaround time should be not more than three business days of the request. Failure to provide the public access file is, in and of itself, considered a compliance failure, regardless of whether there was any intent to deceive or inaccuracies in LCA attestations. However, as the [[H-1B Visa Reform Act of 2004]] clarifies, violations will not be cited in case of good faith efforts to comply, if records are corrected within 10 days, and there is no general pattern of willful violations.<ref name=dol-summary/>
It is generally advised not to include any information in the public access file beyond that mandated by law, since additional information can compromise the privacy of employees and of the company. The additional information that may be demanded in an audit, such as payroll records, full details of wage calculations and H-1B dependency calculations, and evidence of duration of notice posting, needs to be maintained in a private access file.
== References ==
{{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:United States immigration law]] [[Category:United States Department of Labor]]

{{advert|date=September 2018}} '''Qivicon''' is an alliance of companies from different industries<ref>Kuhn, Lothar et al. ''Kleine Muskeln, große Fische''. Wirtschaftswoche. 31.03.2014.</ref> that was founded in 2011 by [[Deutsche Telekom]].<ref>Qivicon Press release headed [https://www.qivicon.com/meta/presse/aktuelles/vernetztes-haus-telekom-plattform-qivicon-ehemals-smart-connect-ermoeglicht-steuerung-von-waschmaschinen-heizung-und-photovoltaik-anlagen/ ''Vernetztes Haus: Telekom Plattform Qivicon (ehemals ‘Smart Connect’) ermöglicht Steuerung von Waschmaschinen, Heizung und Photovoltaik-Anlagen.''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140509001324/https://www.qivicon.com/meta/presse/aktuelles/vernetztes-haus-telekom-plattform-qivicon-ehemals-smart-connect-ermoeglicht-steuerung-von-waschmaschinen-heizung-und-photovoltaik-anlagen/ |date=May 9, 2014 }} 02.09.2011.</ref> The companies are collaborating on a cross-vendor, wireless-based home automation solution that has been available in the German market since fall 2013.<ref>[http://www.wallstreet-online.de/nachricht/6842522-frost-sullivan-recognizes-deutsche-telekom-s-visionary-excellence-leveraging-the-dynamics-within-the-european-connected-living-ecosystem ''Frost & Sullivan Recognizes Deutsche Telekom's Visionary Excellence in Leveraging the Dynamics within the European Connected Living Ecosystem'']. Wallstreet-online.de. 30.06.2014.</ref> It includes products in the areas of energy, security, and comfort. Qivicon won repeat awards from the international management consulting company [[Frost & Sullivan]]’s. In 2016, Frost & Sullivan has awarded Qivicon with the European Connected Home New Product Innovation Award. In 2014, the smart home platform has been awarded with the European Visionary Innovation Leadership Award in recognition of what the management consulting company saw as the most innovative Smart Home solution of the year.<ref>[http://ww2.frost.com/news/press-releases/frost-sullivan-applauds-deutsche-telekoms-breakthrough-innovation-european-connected-home-market-qivicon-smart-home-platform ''Frost & Sullivan Applauds Deutsche Telekom’s Breakthrough Innovation for the European Connected Home Market'']. Frost & Sullivan, August 22, 2016</ref>
== Aims == Qivicon has stated that it would like to take the [[Home Automation|"Smart Home"]] further forward around the world.<ref>Philpott, Michael. Deutsche Telekom continues to expand its Qivicon smart home platform, https://ovum.informa.com/resources/product-content/ces006-000016</ref> Its aim is to establish a vendor-neutral solution that enables users to combine different brands of Smart Home solutions and thereby makes home automation possible for everyone.<ref>Hauptfleisch, Klaus. [http://www.computerwoche.de/a/smart-home-erobert-den-massenmarkt,2555643/ ''Smart Home erobert den Massenmarkt.''] Computerwoche.de. 25.03.2014.</ref><ref>Rodrigues, Stéphane. [http://www.cleantechrepublic.com/2014/03/06/operateurs-telecoms-marche-energie/ ''Des opérateur télécoms se diversifient dans le marché de l’énergie.''] cleantechrepublic.com. 06.03.2014.</ref> The alliance uses Smart Home optimized wireless protocols to make solutions easy to install in any home without needing to lay cables. Qivicon reckons that a Smart Home solution will be all the more attractive for the user the more companies offer compatible devices for use in different areas. The technical platform is international and open for companies of all sizes and in all industries.<ref>Rockmann, Thomas. Telecoms.com http://telecoms.com/opinion/an-evolution-in-integration-the-smart-home-is-on-the-rise/</ref> Qivicon wants to enable its partners to gain access to the Smart Home market with the aid of a technical platform, thereby enabling them to make use of the new market and open up new business models.
== Members == It currently consists of over 43 companies in different industries such as energy, electrical and household appliances, security and telecommunications.<ref>[http://smart-grid.tmcnet.com/news/2014/03/07/7712804.htm ''Deutsche Telekom plugs into the future with digital ‘Steckerleiste’.''] Smart-grid.tmcnet.com. 07.03.2014.</ref><ref>Griesel, Frank: [http://www.bundesbaublatt.de/artikel/bbb_Smarte_Haussteuerung_1950010.html/ ''Smarte Haussteuerung.''] Bundesbaublatt. 07.03.2014.</ref> Qivicon partners include [[Deutsche Telekom]], E wie Einfach, eQ-3, [[Miele]], [[Samsung]] and [[Philips]].<ref>http://www.smarthome.telekom.net/our-portfolio</ref> In March 2018, Deutsche Telekom announced that it had integrated the Home Connect platform, which works with Bosch and Siemens connected devices, into Qivicon to enable greater functunality between the two. For example, as well as being able to control connected Bosch and Siemens appliances directly via the Home Connect app. DT also announced a number of new compatible devices broaden the Qivicon portfolio, such as the Nest Protect smoke and CO alarm.
*[[EnBW]] * eQ-3 *[[Miele]] *[[Samsung]] *[[Deutsche Telekom]] *[[Assa Abloy]] * bitronvideo * Centralite *Cosmote *digitalSTROM *[[D-Link]] * DOM Technologies * Entega * E WIE EINFACH * eww Gruppe *[[Gigaset]] * Google *[[Huawei]] * Hitch *Home Connect *Junkers *[[kpn]] *[[Logitech]] * Nest *[[Netatmo]] *[[Osram]] * PaX *[[Philips]] * Plugwise *[[RheinEnergie AG|RheinEnergie]] * Sengled *Smappee *[[Sonos]] * Stadtwerke Bonn * VW
== Platform == The Qivicon platform has been around in the German market since the fall of 2013. It connects and combines controllable devices made by different manufacturers. Every partner company can market their product offer of its own and develop apps to control them. To date, the product portfolio consists of devices such as motion detectors, smoke detectors, water detectors, wireless adapters for power outlets, door and window contact, temperature and humidity sensors, wireless switches, carbon monoxide sensors, thermostats, cameras, household appliances (e. g. washing machines, dryers, coffee machines), weather stations, sound systems and lighting controls.<ref>Qivicon. [https://www.qivicon.com/assets/Products/Uploads/QIVICON-Kompatibilitaetsliste.pdf ''List of compatible products'']. qivicon.com. 18.07.2014.</ref>
The platform’s technical control unit, its home base, is connected to the Internet via a broadband connection in the house or apartment.<ref>''Das Haus wird intelligent.'' Ratgeber bauen: Traumhäuser. 31.03.2014.</ref> In August 2016, Qivicon launched a new generation of the home base focusing on international markets. The range of different models will keep up with the diverse range of wireless protocols found throughout the international market. The models all have an identical outward appearance. But they differ in terms of their pre-installed protocols. For example, the model designed for the German market, and several other markets, already includes the protocols HomeMatic, ZigBee Pro and the inclusion of HomeMatic IP and DECT ULE has also been completed. Another model includes the ZigBee Pro and Z-Wave radio modules. All versions of the new home base can be connected to home DSL routers either by cable, wirelessly, via Wi-Fi or via Deutsche Telekom´s Speedport Smart router.<ref>QIVICON growing – new markets, new partner offers [https://www.telekom.com/en/media/media-information/enterprise-solutions/qivicon-growing---new-markets--new-partner-offers-436236 ''QIVICON growing – new markets, new partner offers'']. 22.08.2016</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iot-now.com/2017/05/25/62360-speedport-now-controls-deutsche-telekoms-end-user-offering-making-1-2-million-smart-routers-every-year/|title=Speedport to now control Deutsche Telekom’s end-user offering - IoT Now - How to run an IoT enabled business|date=2017-05-25|work=IoT Now - How to run an IoT enabled business|access-date=2018-07-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
The system can be expanded to include other wireless standards by means of USB sticks for which there are four corresponding slots in the home base of the first generation and two slots in the second generation.<ref>Sietmann, Richard. [http://www.heise.de/ct/heft/2014-8-Neue-Strategien-fuer-die-intelligente-Heimvernetzung-2150506.html/ ''Häuserkampf.''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140523234707/http://www.heise.de/ct/heft/2014-8-Neue-Strategien-fuer-die-intelligente-Heimvernetzung-2150506.html/ |date=May 23, 2014 }} c’t Magazin Online, 19.03.2014.</ref> Qivicon partners’ devices can be controlled and monitored via various partner apps for the smartphone, the tablet or the PC.<ref>Brajkovic, Sandra: [https://www.welt.de/print/welt_kompakt/webwelt/article125356501/Daheim-in-der-Zukunft.html/ ''Daheim in der Zukunft.''] Welt.de, 03.03.2014.</ref> Since November 2017 Qivicon is compatible with Alexa from Amazon. Users can control lights, blinds or alarm systems with their voice via Amazon Echo or Google Home.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telekom.com/en/media/media-information/consumer-products/new-mart-home-devices-517580|title=Deutsche Telekom: New partnerships and devices for increased security and comfort in your smart home|last=AG|first=Deutsche Telekom|website=www.telekom.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-26}}</ref>
In March 2017, Deutsche Telekom launched a White Label Smart Home portfolio<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://enterpriseiotinsights.com/20170329/internet-of-things/deutsche-telekom-unveils-while-label-smart-home-platform-tag23|title=Deutsche Telekom unveils While Label Smart Home platform|last=Tomás|first=Juan Pedro|date=2017-03-29|work=Enterprise IoT Insights|access-date=2018-07-26|language=en-US}}</ref> that includes platform, gateways, applications, compatible devices and services. The portfolio is designed to help telecommunications service providers, utility providers, hardware manufacturers and other enterprises create and offer smart home services.
Deutsche Telekom extended its international footprint within the smart home sector by partnering with Cosmote, the largest mobile operator in Greece and part of the OTE group, as well as Hitch in Norway, adding Greece and Norway to Qivicon's current footprint of Germany, Slovakia, the Netherlands, Austria, and Italy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ovum.informa.com/resources/product-content/ces006-000016|title=Deutsche Telekom continues to expand Qivicon smart home platform|last=Philpott|first=Michael|date=|website=ovum.informa.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.iteuropa.com/news/deutsche-telekom-norwegian-smart-home-push|title=Deutsche Telekom in Norwegian smart home push|last=Garratt|first=Jon|date=2018-05-17|work=ITEuropa|access-date=2018-07-26|language=en}}</ref>
AV-Test, an IT security test institution, rates Qivicon as “secure”.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.qivicon.com/en/meta/media-relations/the-qivicon-smart-home-platform-provides-outstanding-protection|title=The QIVICON smart home platform provides outstanding protection - QIVICON|website=www.qivicon.com|language=en-EN|access-date=2018-07-26}}</ref> It found that the Smart Home platform used encryption for communication and provided protection from unauthorized access.
== References == <references />
== Bibliography == Ohland, Günther. ''Smart-Living.'' Books on Demand, Norderstedt 2013. {{ISBN|978-3-7322923-0-1}}.
== External links == * [https://www.qivicon.com/ Qivicon home page]

revision.text:
'''''Qimron v. Shanks''''', (2000) is a landmark ruling by the [[Israeli Supreme Court]]. The Court ruled that an Israeli scholar had a copyright on his reconstruction of an important [[Dead Sea Scrolls|Dead Sea Scroll]] and that his right had been violated by an unauthorized early publication of his work.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/08/31/world/israeli-court-upholds-scholar-s-rights-to-dead-sea-scrolls-work.html|title=Israeli Court Upholds Scholar's Rights to Dead Sea Scrolls Work|last=Greenberg|first=Joel|date=2000-08-31|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-15|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
== Background == More than eight-hundred scrolls, including the oldest known copies of [[Old Testament]] books, are thought to have been written between the second century B.C. and A.D. 70 were discovered in 1947 near the [[Dead Sea]] in caves at [[Qumran Caves|Qumran]] on the [[West Bank]].
Thereafter they were held at a museum in [[East Jerusalem]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=MacQueen|first=Hector L.|date=2010-10-28|title=The Scrolls and the Legal Definition of Authorship|url=http://www.oxfordhandbooks.com/view/10.1093/oxfordhb/9780199207237.001.0001/oxfordhb-9780199207237-e-31|language=en|doi=10.1093/oxfordhb/9780199207237.001.0001/oxfordhb-9780199207237-e-31}}</ref> In 1967, the museum came under Israeli control following the [[Six-Day War|Six‐Day War]] between [[Israel]], [[Egypt]], [[Jordan]] and [[Syria]].<ref name=":1" /> While this brought the work on the scrolls under the auspices of the [[Israel Antiquities Authority|Israeli Antiquities Authority]], this did not otherwise affect the work of an international team of scholars who had been appointed in 1953/54 to transcribe, edit, and publish the fragments found in Cave 4 at Qumran. It did however lead to resentment from scholars outside the team who were denied any access to the unpublished scrolls.<ref name=":1" />
== Ruling == It was the first in which [[copyright law]] had been applied in court to a reconstruction of an ancient document.<ref name=":0" />
== References == <references />
[[Category:Copyright law]] [[Category:2000 in Israel]]

{{Use Australian English|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox court case | name = The Owners of the S.S. Kalibia v Alexander Wilson | full name = | court = [[High Court of Australia]] | image = Coat of Arms of Australia.svg | date decided = 30 March 1910 | citations = {{cite AustLII|HCA|77|1970|parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1910/77.pdf (1910) 11 {{abbr|CLR|Commonwealth Law Reports}} 689]}} | judges = [[Samuel Griffith|Griffith]] [[Chief Justice of Australia|CJ]], [[Edmund Barton|Barton]], [[Richard O'Connor (politician)|O'Connor]], [[Isaac Isaacs|Isaacs]] & [[H. B. Higgins|Higgins]] [[Justices|JJ]] | prior actions = ''In re Wilson'' (1910) 27 [[Weekly Notes (New South Wales)|WN (NSW)]] 73 per Gordon J |appealed from = [[Supreme Court of New South Wales|Supreme Court (NSW)]] | subsequent actions = | opinions = }} '''''SS Kalibia v Wilson''''',<ref name=Kalibia>{{cite AustLII|HCA|77|1970|litigants=SS Kalibia v Wilson |parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1910/77.pdf (1910) 11 {{abbr|CLR|Commonwealth Law Reports}} 689] |courtname=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]]}}.</ref> was the first decision of the [[High Court of Australia]] on the extent of the power of the [[Parliament of Australia|Australian Parliament]] to make laws about shipping and navigation, including the [[Admiralty jurisdiction]] of the High Court. The High Court held that the power was limited to overseas and interstate trade and commerce. There was no separate power about navigation and shipping.<ref name="ALRC"/><ref name="Allsop 2007"/>
==Background== ===The Constitution=== [[Section 51 of the Constitution of Australia|Section 51 of the Constitution]] provides that the Australian Parliament has the power to make laws with respect to: :(i) trade and commerce with other countries, and among the States;<ref name="s51">{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|coaca430|Constitution|51}} Legislative powers of the Parliament.</ref>
[[Section 98 of the Constitution of Australia|Section 98 of the Constitution]] then provides that : The power of the Parliament to make laws with respect to trade and commerce extends to navigation and shipping, and to railways the property of any State.<ref name="s98">{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|coaca430|Constitution|98}} Trade and commerce includes navigation and State railways.</ref>
The Parliament can also make laws conferring [[Section 76 of the Constitution of Australia|original jurisdiction on the High Court]] in any matter of Admiralty and maritime jurisdiction.<ref name="s76">{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|coaca430|Constitution|76}} Additional original jurisdiction.</ref>
The early drafts of the Constitution gave the Australian parliament power to make laws with respect to "navigation and shipping" as a separate head of power under section 51. In 1898 the drafting committee made two relevant changes, to remove shipping and navigation to section 98 and to make it a part of the trade and commerce power in section 51(1). It is not apparent from the debates why this was done, nor was there any apparent consideration as to the effect of the change.<ref name="3 Mar 98">{{cite web |title=Official Record of the Debates of the Australasian Federal Convention, Melbourne, 3 March 1898 |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;query=Id%3A%22constitution%2Fconventions%2F1898-1121%22}}</ref><ref name="16 Mar 98">{{cite web |title=Official Record of the Debates of the Australasian Federal Convention, Melbourne, 16 March 1898 |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;query=Id%3A%22constitution%2Fconventions%2F1898-1129%22}}</ref><ref name="Allsop 2007">{{cite web|last1=Allsop |first1=James |author-link1=James Allsop |title=Australian Admiralty and Maritime Law – sources and future directions |url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/journals/UQLawJl/2007/10.pdf}} (2007) 26 University of Queensland Law Journal 179.</ref>
===The Seamen's Compensation Act=== The ''Seamen's Compensation Act'' was a uniform law that applied to all seamen on Australian registered ships and to Australian seamen on British and foreign ships engaged in the Australian [[coasting trade]]. The coasting trade was defined as carrying cargo from one port in Australia to another, even if those ports were in the same State.<ref name=Act>{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|num_act|sca1909291909249|Seamen's Compensation Act 1909}}</ref><ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=Senate |title=Seamen's Compensation Bill |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/download/hansard80/hansards80/1909-07-21/toc_pdf/19090721_senate_3_50.pdf |date=21 July 1909 |page_start=1405 |page_end=1413 |speaker=[[Edward Millen]] |position=[[Vice-President of the Executive Council]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |title=Seamen's Compensation Bill |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/download/hansard80/hansardr80/1909-12-03/toc_pdf/19091203_reps_3_54.pdf |date=3 December 1909 |page_start=6930 |page_end=6931 |speaker=[[Paddy Glynn]] |position=[[Attorney-General for Australia|Attorney-General]]}}</ref> Because the [[Section 51(i) of the Constitution of Australia|trade and commerce power]] is limited to overseas and inter-state trade, there needed to be some other head of federal power to support its validity in providing for intrastate trade. The Commonwealth argued this power was found in sections 76(iii) and 98 of the Constitution.<ref>The argument referred to {{cite book |last1=Moore |first=W H |author-link1=William Harrison Moore |title=The constitution of the commonwealth of Australia |edition=2nd |year=1910 |url=https://archive.org/details/constitutionofco00moor |page=560}}</ref>
===The Facts===
The [[SS Kalibia (1902)|Kalibia]] was a British [[Ship registration|flagged]] [[screw steamer]] (SS) owned by the [[Clyde Shipping Company]] of Glasgow, that in 1909 had been chartered to carry cargo from New York to Australia, offloading cargo at Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane. The [[Chief mate|first officer]] agreed to transport a small package from Adelaide to Brisbane that had been mistakenly offloaded from another cargo ship. It was alleged that the SS Kalibia had taken horses from Melbourne to Brisbane, but this was later agreed to be wrong.
In Melbourne the crew, described as [[Lascars]], deserted the ship, complaining of being ill-treated and underfed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article10849666 |title=Kalibia's Lascars refuse to rejoin vessel |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |date=16 April 1910 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> On arrival in Sydney the men were charged with combining to disobey lawful commands and were sentenced to imprisonment for 6 weeks, being the time the vessel would be absent from Sydney, at the end of which they would be placed on the vessel for the homeward journey.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15136833 |title=Trouble on the Kalibia |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=26 April 1910 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
The crew were replaced for the voyage to Brisbane by an Australia crew, including Alexander Wilson. Wilson was seriously injured on 29 April 1910 when he was knocked into the [[hold (ship)|vessel's hold]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article19632722 |title=Accident to a Seaman |newspaper=[[The Brisbane Courier]] |date=2 May 1910 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> He applied to the [[Supreme Court of New South Wales|Supreme Court of NSW]] for an order that the ship be detained until a security bond was paid to cover any compensation that might be awarded to Wilson. [[Philip Whistler Street|Justice Street]] made an order in the absence of the owners of the SS Kalibia ([[Ex parte#Australia|ex parte]]). The owners sought to have the order set aside however Justice Gordon refused, holding that there was some evidence that the ship was engaged in the coasting trade and whether this was correct was a matter to be determined at trial. If the ship was permitted to depart Australia without providing security then Wilson would have no recourse.<ref>''In re Wilson'' (1910) 27 [[Weekly Notes (New South Wales)|WN (NSW)]] 73, [[Supreme Court of New South Wales|Supreme Court (NSW)]].</ref> The security was subsequently set by consent at £500.
==The High Court==
===Nature of the order=== It was argued for Wilson that the order of Street J was "ministerial" rather than judicial and as such Gordon J had no jurisdiction to discharge the order and there was no appeal to the High Court. Griffith CJ was the only judge to deal with this argument in detail, holding that a power conferred upon a judicial officer was judicial unless there were "clear words to show that it was dictatorial and unappealable". It was an elementary rule of justice that a party affected by an ex-parte order could apply to have the order discharged.
===The coasting trade=== Wilson had been engaged in Australia on a British ship, the critical point for the success of his application was whether the Kalibia was engaged in the coasting trade which required loading cargo in one Australian port to be unloaded at another. The only thing taken on board in Australia was the small case carried by the first officer as a favour for a shipping agent. Griffith CJ held that the essence of trade was a contract of carriage made on behalf of the ship and the case was therefore not cargo.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|p. 696}} Barton J similarly held that gratuitous carriage was not sufficient and that trading in this context connoted payment for freight.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|p. 700}} O'Connor J held that the isolated transaction had no trace of trade or business and was not conducted with the authority of the owners.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|p. 706}} Isaacs J also held that the captain had no apparent authority to engage in the coasting trade.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|p. 711}}
===The Act was unconstitutional=== The court's finding that the Kalibia was not engaged in the coasting trade meant it was unnecessary to decide the constitutional validity of the Act, and the Court would not normally do so.<ref>{{cite AustLII|HCA|64|1908|link=Attorney-General for NSW v Brewery Employees Union of NSW |litigants=Union Label case |parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1908/94.pdf (1908) 6 {{abbr|CLR|Commonwealth Law Reports}} 469] |courtname=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]]}} at pp. 491–492 per Griffith CJ and pp. 553–554 per Isaacs J.</ref> On this occasion however each of the judges felt it was appropriate to express their opinion on the validity of the Act. albeit Higgins J did so with considerable reservation. One objection was that compensation for seamen did not fall within trade and commerce. None of the judges determined this objection. Each of the judges held that by including all coasting trade in Australia, including intrastate trade, the Act went beyond the Commonwealth power. Section 98 of the constitution explained the meaning of "trade and commence" and did not remove the need for such trade to be "with other countries, and among the States". There are echoes of the [[reserved powers doctrine]] in the judgments of Griffiths CJ, Barton and O'Connor JJ however their judgments were not based on it. Isaacs and Higgins JJ, who steadfastly rejected the reserved powers doctrine, similarly found that there was no constitutional power to regulate shipping and navigation within the limits of a State.
Where the judges differed was in applying the test from the decided cases,<ref name="Railway servants">{{cite AustLII|HCA|94|1906|litigants=Railway servants case |link=Federated Amalgamated Government Railway & Tramway Service Association v NSW Rail Traffic Employees Association |parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1906/94.pdf (1906) 4 {{abbr|CLR|Commonwealth Law Reports}} 488] |courtname=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]]}}.</ref><ref name="No 2">{{cite AustLII|HCA|33|1910|litigants=Whybrows case (No 2) |link=Australian Boot Trade Employees' Federation v Whybrow & Co#R v Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration; Ex parte Whybrow & Co (No 2) |parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1910/33.pdf (1910) 11 {{abbr|CLR|Commonwealth Law Reports}} 1] |courtname=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]]}}.</ref> whether the invalid provisions could be severed. Griffith CJ held that the Act intended to apply to all ships engaged in the coasting trade without distinction and that the provisions could not therefore be severed.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|p. 699}} Barton J held that the definition of coasting trade was unambiguous and it was not the role of the Court to re-write the definition to make it constitutional.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|p. 702}} O'Connor J held that the provisions of the Act could not be separated, such that the entire Act was invalid.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|p. 708}} Isaacs J held that Parliament had made no distinction between inter-State and intra-State trade and that the enactment was therefore invalid.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|p. 715}}
Higgins J dissented on the question of severability. His Honour had no doubt the Parliament intended the Act to apply to the coasting trade within the limits of a State, but that if Parliament had understood the limits of its power, the Act would have been limited to inter-State seamen.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|pp. 721–2}}
===s76(iii)=== The Commonwealth argued that the Act was a valid exercise of power under section 76(iii) of the Constitution, asserting that "the Parliament may make laws in any matter of admiralty and maritime jurisdiction". That is that the power to give the High Court jurisdiction with respect to admiralty and maritime matters implied a power on the part of the Commonwealth tho legislate as to those matters. Griffith CJ described the argument as quite untenable.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|p. 699}} Barton J held that this was a matter in which the over-riding power on the subject was the Parliament of the United Kingdom.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|pp. 703–4}} Isaacs J noted that section 76 related solely to Parliament conferring original jurisdiction on the High Court. His Honour distinguished between the interpretation and enforcement of admiralty and maritime law and the alteration of that law.<ref name=Kalibia/>{{rp|p. 715}}
==Aftermath== The effect of the decision was that the Australian Parliament did not have power to alter maritime law or to deal with maritime affairs other than by reliance upon the heads of power in s 51, importantly (but not solely) the trade and commerce power.<ref name=Samson>{{cite AustLII|FCAFC|182|2014|litigants=Samson Maritime Pty Ltd v Aucote |parallelcite=(2014) 229 [[Federal Court Reports|FCR]] 125 |pinpoint=[34] |courtname=[[Federal Court of Australia|Federal Court (Full Court)]]}}.</ref> The decision has never been over-turned by the High Court, however doubts have been expressed about the legitimacy of the High Court's decision, with Higgins J describing the views on the reach of s 76(iii) expressed by Griffiths CJ, Barton and Isaacs JJ as [[Obiter dicta|obiter]].<ref>{{cite AustLII|HCA|15|1927|litigants=R v Turner; Ex parte Marine Board of Hobart |parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1927/15.pdf (1927) 39 {{abbr|CLR|Commonwealth Law Reports}} 411] at pp 447–8 |courtname=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]]}}.</ref> More recently [[William Gummow|Justice Gummow]], then sitting in the [[Federal Court of Australia|Federal Court]], noted that Barton J's reasoning that Australia was not, in 1910, a "separated nation of independent sovereignty in its relation to the United Kingdom" no longer represented the modern constitutional position.<ref>{{cite AustLII|FCA|499|1991|litigants=Re Empire Shipping Company Inc v the Owners of the Ship "Shin Kobe Maru" |parallelcite=(1991) 32 [[Federal Court Reports|FCR]] 78 at pp 86–7 |courtname=[[Federal Court of Australia|Federal Court]]}}.</ref>
A replacement ''Seamen's Compensation Act'' was passed in 1911, which was limited in its application to ships engaged in trade and commerce with other countries or among the States.<ref>{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|num_act|sca191113o1911268|Seamen's Compensation Act 1911}}</ref> The 1911 Act was challenged in ''[[Australian Steamships Ltd v Malcolm]]'' on the basis that compensation for seamen did not fall within trade and commerce. The majority, Isaacs, Gavan Duffy, Powers and Rich JJ (Griffith CJ & Barton J dissenting) held that the Act was a valid exercise of the trade and commerce power.<ref>{{cite AustLII|FCA|73|1914|litigants=[[Australian Steamships Ltd v Malcolm]] |parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1914/73.pdf (1914) 19 {{abbr|CLR|Commonwealth Law Reports}} 298] |courtname=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]]}}.</ref>
In the ''Navigation Act'' 1912 (Cth) the Parliament sought to overcome the question of severability by the inclusion of a provision that the Act was to be "construed subject to the Constitution, and so as not to exceed the legislative power of the Commonwealth"<ref>{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|num_act|na19124o1913169|Navigation Act 1912}}</ref> a provision that, in 1930, would be added to the [[Acts Interpretation Act 1901|''Acts Interpretation Act'']].<ref>{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|aia1901230|Acts Interpretation Act|15A}} Construction of Acts to be subject to Constitution.</ref> There are limitations to the effectiveness of such an approach.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.opc.gov.au/about/docs/drafting_series/DD3.1.pdf |title=Drafting Direction No. 3.1 Constitutional law issues |publisher=Office of Parliamentary Counsel (Cth) |date=January 2017}}</ref>
The [[Australian Law Reform Commission]] was asked to review all aspects of the Admiralty jurisdiction in Australia and chapter 5 of its report looked at both the history of the jurisdiction in Australia and made various recommendations for change, including the use of other constitutional heads of power as the foundation for Australian legislation. The report noted that the High Court had held in the [[New South Wales v Commonwealth (1975)|Sea and Submerged lands case]],<ref>{{cite AustLII|HCA|58|1975|litigants=NSW v Commonwealth ('Seas and Submerged Lands case) |link=New South Wales v Commonwealth (1975) |parallelcite=(1975) 135 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 337 |courtname=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]]}}.</ref> that the territory of the States stopped at the low-water mark or at the line closing a bay, such that the [[Section 51(xxix) of the Constitution of Australia|external affairs power]] would permit the Parliament to make laws about ships voyaging from one port in Australia to another, even if those ports were in the same State.<ref name="ALRC">{{cite web|publisher=[[Australian Law Reform Commission]] |title=Civil Admiralty Jurisdiction |url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/other/lawreform/ALRC/1986/33.html}}</ref> The Parliament subsequently enacted the ''Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act'' 1992 which relied upon additional heads of power, including the [[Section 51(xx) of the Constitution of Australia|corporations power]].<ref>{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|sraca1992381|Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992}}</ref> In 2014 a Full Court of the Federal Court held that this meant the Act was effective in regulating the rights of employees of a trading corporation who worked on a vessel that was working in an area confined to the seas off Western Australia. The Court held it was unnecessary to decide the complex questions, arising from the decision in ''SS Kalibia v Wilson'' around whether the employer's business dealings were such that the ship was engaged in overseas or interstate trade or commerce.<ref name=Samson/>
===The referendums=== The [[Australian Labor Party|Labor Party]] twice held [[Referendums in Australia|referendums]] to consider proposed changes to the Constitution to overcome the decision of the High Court by removing the limitation on the trade and commerce power to be with other countries or among the States. Neither referendum was successful.
{| class="wikitable" |+ Results<ref name="Handbook">Handbook of the 44th Parliament (2014) {{cite web |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;query=Id%3A%22handbook%2Fnewhandbook%2F2014-10-31%2F0049%22 |title=Part 5 – Referendums and Plebiscites – Referendum results |publisher=[[Parliamentary Library of Australia]] |archive-url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;query=Id%3A%22handbook%2Fnewhandbook%2F2014-10-31%2F0049%22 |archive-date=29 September 2017 |dead-url=no}}</ref> |----- ! align="left" | Year | | Question ! style="width:50px" align=center | [[New South Wales|NSW]] ! style="width:50px" align=center | [[Victoria, Australia|Vic]] ! style="width:50px" align=center | [[Queensland|Qld]] ! style="width:50px" align=center | [[South Australia|SA]] ! style="width:50px" align=center | [[Western Australia|WA]] ! style="width:50px" align=center | [[Tasmania|Tas]] ! style="width:70px" align=center |'''States in favour''' ! style="width:70px" align=center |''' Voters in favour''' ! | '''Result''' |- | [[Australian referendum, 1911|1911]] | align="right" | (4) [[Australian referendum, 1911 (Trade and Commerce)|Trade and Commerce]] | {{No|36.11%}} | {{No|38.64%}} | {{No|43.75%}} | {{no|38.07%}} | {{Yes|54.86%}} | {{No|42.11%}} | {{No|1:5}} | {{No|39.42%}} | {{No|'''Not carried'''}} |- | [[Australian referendum, 1913|1913]] | (6) [[Australian referendum, 1913 (Trade and Commerce)|Trade and Commerce]] | {{No|46.96%}} | {{No|49.12%}} | {{Yes|54.34%}} | {{Yes|51.32%}} | {{Yes|52.86%}} | {{No|45.16%}} | {{No|3:3}} | {{No|49.38%}} | {{No|'''Not carried'''}} |}
[[Writ of election|Writs]] were issued for a further referendum to be held on 11 December 1915 to cover substantially the same questions as were rejected in 1911 and 1913,<ref>{{cite book |title=Amendment of Constitution, Federal referendums, the case for and against |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.obj-52788225/view?partId=nla.obj-92475589 |date=16 September 1915 |publisher=Chief Electoral Officer for the Commonwealth |pages=27–28}}</ref> however the referendum was cancelled and the writs withdrawn.<ref>{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|num_act|raa21915511915446|Referendum (Constitution Alteration) (No 2) 1915}}</ref>
===The SS Kalibia=== On [[List of shipwrecks in November 1917#30 November|30 November 1917]], the SS Kalibia was in the Atlantic Ocean {{convert|29|nmi|km}} south west of [[The Lizard]], Cornwall ({{coord|49|31|N|5|32|W}}) when it was torpedoed and sunk by the [[Imperial German Navy|German]] submarine {{SMU|UB-80||6}} with the loss of 25 of her crew.<ref name=NH33>{{cite web |url=http://www.naval-history.net/WW1LossesBrMS1918.htm |title= British merchant ships lost to enemy action Part 3 of 3 – September 1917 – November 1918 in date order |publisher=Naval History |accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref>
